title: klu9's ZeroBlog
description:
Just a user, not a coder.
Interested in ZeroNet's potential for a web less vulnerable to:
° regulatory capture (e.g. copyright laws dictated by lobby groups) 
° takedowns (e.g. DMCA, EUCD, Article 13, domain seizures)
° blocks (e.g. ISPs, GFW)
° net partiality (e.g. preferential treatment for privileged content providers)
° corporate acquisitions, changes, neglect or demise (e.g. GeoCities, del.icio.us, Flickr, Tumblr)
° individual change, neglect or demise (e.g. linkrot; webmaster losing interest, disappearing or dying)
° money-making shennanigans supposedly justified by the cost of providing a service (e.g. advertising, tracking, privacy violations)
° bloat (wait for a 10MB page to load just so you can read a 10KB article)
° connection problems (as 0net can cache sites)

[klu9's media share](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1NEuAUKgUoY6fnXeXBaonjrDfNbfpQpdMp/?Home)
[The Papers](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1Papers8S7fe6LEsa7BwVVywWVbMpUjgwx/)
[ZeroMe](http://127.0.0.1:43110/Me.ZeroNetwork.bit/?Profile/12h51ug6CcntU2aiBjhP8Ns2e5VypbWWtv/131Seivv6aH8vnohPmYPcPwPfZ1a5ubMMs/klu9@zeroid.bit)

post.title: WebP for comics with free tool CbxConverter
post.body:
[A post on ZeroTalk about uploading comics to ZeroNet](http://127.0.0.1:43110/Talk.ZeroNetwork.bit/?Topic:1555521255_1ME9gwj9Exp9cBbuSxxr1mEiySEjmXNA2w/Where+to+put+CBZ+files) led to discussion of alternative formats, like [DjVu](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DjVu) (which I used to use to convert massive file-size JPG scans of textbooks into files that were a fraction of the size and used a lot less of my computer's RAM than PDF, and unlike JPG can contain an OCR/text layer).

I thought "Hey, maybe WebP would useful for comics." And it turns out that (obviously) I wasn't the first to think that. Many comic book viewing programs already support WebP.

I tried converting a comic book page from JPG to WebP myself, using an image editor. But then I found there's a handy tool to convert entire comics to WebP.

+ [CbxConverter](http://tomeko.net/software/CbxConverter/)

CbxConverter is a small basic GUI program for Windows that takes 'standard' [comic book files like .cbz and .cbr](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Comic_book_archive) (basically .zip and .rar files usually containing JPG scans), converts the image files inside from JPG to WebP, and produces a new .cbz with a significantly smaller file size. Just drag & drop the cbz/cbr onto the program and press "Start conversion". After a few minutes, you get a brand new .cbz file at a much smaller size, ready to read in your comic book viewer (in my case [SumatraPDF](https://sumatrapdfreader.org/)). 

![CbxConverter.0.12.2](img/CbxConverter0122.png)

In my brief testing, here's what I got with it.

| No. | Type | Details | Size | Sample page |
| - | - | - | - | - |
| 1. | [Original cbr](http://127.0.0.1:43110/12MVkvYGcRW6u2NYbpfwVad1oQeyG4s9Er/index.html?view:item+id:1Mz2_1Mx5xcSVsv8mdsXtKwBPD8X1SEfzN2VR5u_item_6+type:archive) | containing jpgs | 60 MB | [Jpg: 1,630KB](optional/Batman-Damned-2018-001-006.jpg) |
| 2. | Jpg | Recompressed Q:75 | only 1 page | [Jpg: 1,260KB](optional/Batman-Damned-2018-001-006.75.jpg) |
| 3. | WebP cbz | Default (Quality:75) | 30 MB | [WebP: 821KB](optional/Batman Damned-2018-001-006-cbx-q75.webp) |
| 4. | WebP cbz | Quality:50 | 21 MB | [WebP: 585KB](optional/Batman-Damned-2018-001-006-cbx-q50.webp) |
| 5. | WebP cbz | Resize:66%, Quality:50 | 12 MB | [WebP: 322KB](optional/Batman-Damned-2018-001-006-cbx-q50-66pc.webp) |

(Re 2, I extracted a jpg from original and manually recompressed it as jpg in my image editor at quality 75 to see how that would compare to CbxConverter WebP at 75. I only did that for one page.)

I literally could not tell the difference between No. 1 (60 MB), No. 2, No. 3 (30 MB) and No. 4 (21 MB), at least viewing on my screen and at "Fit Width to Screen". Even at full size most of the time I couldn't tell the difference.

CbxConverter 0.12.2 doesn't allow a free choice for resizing, just a selection of 66%, 50%, 33% or 25%. But with this particular comic, 66% is only a little under my screen's width, so it's a good size. In fact, in a few places it even looks a little *better* than the original (when the original is scaled to fit my screen's width). So for me, No. 5 (12 MB) is practically as good as No. 1 (60 MB). But less than one quarter the file size :)

(For coders, the source is available at the bottom of CbxConverter's homepage.)

Now if only I could find a nice handy tool like CbxConverter but to convert entire comics files to DjVu, so I could compare.

post.title: Getting a vanity address for a zite
post.body:
Standard ZeroNet website addresses, being based on Bitcoin addresses, generally look like a long string of random numbers and letters, beginning with `1`. E.g this site's:
+ `http://127.0.0.1:43110/`**1Ctjcvfovq6d1JWEGvM1JovCym4H6Es33L**`/`

But you may have noticed that a few are not entirely random. E.g. ZeroHello's has `1HeLLo` at the start:
+ `http://127.0.0.1:43110/`**1HeLLo4uzjaLetFx6NH3PMwFP3qbRbTf3D**`/`

You can create an address with your own choice of characters at the start by using a software tool called *vanitygen*. So here I'll write about what I did to get a vanity address for a new zite.
+ [Vanitygen homepage](https://en.bitcoin.it/wiki/Vanitygen)

I based what I did mostly on this guide:
+ [3x71nc7's Blog - How To: custom ZeroNet addresses using Vanitygen](http://127.0.0.1:43110/13x71nc7fju6afMqpEPfcu3Gx9Z5hNhH48/?Post:5:How+To:+custom+ZeroNet+addresses+using+Vanitygen+) (2016-02-27)

However, maybe because that guide is a few years old, or perhaps because I'm just not good enough at all this stuff as the original writer, I found it a little confusing or inconvenient at certain points, and I ended up doing a couple of steps differently. (I thought I might find the issues clarified in the comments, but even though the page says there are 6 comments, I can't see any.)

## **Part 1: Creating a vanity address**

Note: I did this on Windows. There will be slight differences on other operating systems.

### **1. Get *vanitygen* for your operating system.**

Available through the links on [the Vanitygen homepage](https://en.bitcoin.it/wiki/Vanitygen). I'm on Windows so I used the vanitygen contained in [**this zip file**](https://github.com/downloads/samr7/vanitygen/vanitygen-0.22-win.zip).

### **2. Open a terminal emulator / command (CMD) window, and direct it to the location of vanitygen.**
After unzipping the file, I opened a command window. ("Start" > search `cmd`.) Then in the file manager, I copied the path to the vanitygen folder:
+ `C:\Users\klu9\Downloads\vanitygen`

and then in the Command window right-clicked and selected "Paste". (Ctrl+V doesn't work in the command window.)

### **3. Enter the vanitygen program name and the pattern you want your address to begin with**, starting with the obligatory `1`.

All Bitcoin addresses have to begin with `1`.

So in my case I entered into the command window:
+ `vanitygen64.exe 1Papers`

![01vanitygen.png](img/01vanitygen.png)
+ *Vanitygen, a few hours after it started working.*

Don't make the pattern too long, as each additional character increases the time needed exponentially (e.g. if I had chosen `1ThePapers`, those three extra letters could have made the process last for *days*). Vanitygen requires a lot of processing power from your CPU, so before I started the process, I closed every other program.

### **4. Wait while Vanitygen creates your address.**

At the start, Vanitygen told me it would take 10 hours to get 50% of the way to creating the address. In the end that was about how long it took to complete the process fully. During that time, the task manager showed my CPU being used at 99% the whole time. Obviously it's not ideal to do other tasks on the computer while vanitygen is doing its work, so plan this for a time when you won't need your computer for other things.

![02vanitygen.taskmanager.pix.png](img/02vanitygen.taskmanager.pix.png)
+ *Task manager showing CPU at 99% while vanitygen is working. [Full size](img/02vanitygen.taskmanager.pix.png)*

### **5. Save the result.**
At the end of the process, the command window showed me:
+ the pattern I had entered ( `1Papers` )
+ the complete address it generated based on that pattern ( `1Papers8S7fe6LEsa7BwVVywWVbMpUjgwx` )
+ The private key ("privkey"). This is what you will need to "prove" you own this address.

**Keep your private key safe and secret**. This is the only time you will receive it, and if you lose it, it's lost forever.

This part (creating the vanity address) was, although time-consuming, very simple and according to the guide I linked to earlier.

![03vanitygen.result.png](img/03vanitygen.result.png)
+ *Vanitygen showing the results*

----

## **Part 2: Using the address**

I wanted to make a fresh blog based on [ZeroBlog](http://127.0.0.1:43110/Blog.ZeroNetwork.bit/) but with the 1Papers address. Here's how **I** ended up doing it, which may or may not be the best way to do it.

### **1. Create a folder with your new address.**
So in my case inside the folder
+ `C:\Users\klu9\Downloads\ZeroNet-win-dist\data\`

 I created a new folder with the address name, resulting in:
+ `C:\Users\klu9\Downloads\ZeroNet-win-dist\data\1Papers8S7fe6LEsa7BwVVywWVbMpUjgwx`

### A little confusion on my part

Here's where that guide gets a little confusing for me. It says to go into the folder of an existing site and "copy everything". Really? *Everything*? I don't think I want *everything*. Wouldn't that make another version of the existing site with all its associated content and data? Whereas I want to make a fresh, empty site. If I copy *everything*, am I going to have to manually delete lots of stuff to make it a fresh, empty site? If so, which stuff? No answer there.

E.g. I took a look at the folder for ZeroBlog (`\ZeroNet-win-dist\data\1BLogC9LN4oPDcruNz3qo1ysa133E9AGg8`) and just its `\data\users` folder contains 2,606 files in 1,303 folders.

So "everything" would presumably include:
+ all the posts made
+ all media (images, videos etc)
+ all data on users who've visited the zite
+ other?

So, should I instead clone ZeroBlog from scratch and do something with the result? Would doing that create a new key that is then deprived from the pool of available keys?

### **2. Clone ZeroBlog.**

Rather than copy everything from an existing site with data already in it, I decided to make a fresh clone of ZeroBlog.
1. Go to the ZeroHello left menu
2. Find `ZeroBlog`. (If you find lots of similarly named sites in your list, the one I chose was the one by ZeroNet creator @nofish:, whose URL is `http://127.0.0.1:43110/Blog.ZeroNetwork.bit/` when you hover over it in the ZeroHello left menu)
3. Click on the three-dot menu to right of site name and select "**Clone**"

![04.0zerohelloclonezeroblog.png](img/04.0zerohelloclonezeroblog.png)
+ *ZeroHello, cloning ZeroBlog. [Full size](img/04.0zerohelloclonezeroblog.png)*

That created a fresh empty ZeroBlog with the following address:
+ `16xTLL1n8pNfdEx8888CivfHGwFj926h8r`

Which opened automatically in my browser, showing the "Congratulations" message.

![04zeroblog.clone.16xTLL.png](img/04zeroblog.clone.16xTLL.png)
+ *New clone of ZeroBlog, with `16xTLL1n8pNfdEx8888CivfHGwFj926h8r` as its address. [Full size](img/04zeroblog.clone.16xTLL.png)*

### **3. Copy everything from new blog folder into the folder of your vanity address.**
So in my case I copied everything from
+ `C:\Users\klu9\Downloads\ZeroNet-win-dist\data\16xTLL1n8pNfdEx8888CivfHGwFj926h8r`

into
+ `C:\Users\klu9\Downloads\ZeroNet-win-dist\data\1Papers8S7fe6LEsa7BwVVywWVbMpUjgwx`.


### **4. Open the new address in your browser.**

I opened http://127.0.0.1:43110/1Papers8S7fe6LEsa7BwVVywWVbMpUjgwx/ and got the "Congratulations" message. Yay :)

![05zeroblog.clone.1papers.png](img/05zeroblog.clone.1papers.png)
+ *New clone of ZeroBlog, with `1Papers8S7fe6LEsa7BwVVywWVbMpUjgwx` as its address. [Full size](img/05zeroblog.clone.1papers.png)*

### **5. Open the new site's sidebar.**
Click and drag the ZeroNet icon (near the top right of the page) to the left, and let it go.

![06zeroblog.clone.1papers.sidebar.1.png](img/06zeroblog.clone.1papers.sidebar.1.png)
+ *Initial sidebar. [Full size](img/06zeroblog.clone.1papers.sidebar.1.png)*

### **6. Scroll down the sidebar and click "This is my site."**
![07zeroblog.clone.1papers.sidebar.2.png](img/07zeroblog.clone.1papers.sidebar.2.png)
+ *Sidebar, lower down. [Full size](img/07zeroblog.clone.1papers.sidebar.2.png)*

More stuff will now appear below in the sidebar.



### **7. Edit your site's details in the site sidebar.**
In my case:
+ SITE TITLE > The Papers
+ SITE DESCRIPTION > UK newspapers blog mirror

Then I clicked "**Save site settings**".

![08zeroblog.clone.1papers.sidebar.3.png](img/08zeroblog.clone.1papers.sidebar.3.png)
+ *Sidebar, additional features after clicking "This is my site". [Full size](img/08zeroblog.clone.1papers.sidebar.3.png)*

### **8. ???**
Here the guide gives an instruction that was unclear for me.
> Open content.json with a text editor and check that no domain it set.

> If it is, delete it.

I don't know what/where such a domain is, but my site works, so I guess I'm OK.

### **9. Add the private key.**
The guide's next step says to shut down ZeroNet and then run a terminal / command window to sign the site. But the sidebar has a button for this. (Maybe it didn't back when the guide was written three years ago.) The sidebar also has a link "ADD SAVED PRIVATE KEY".

(What about the identity address? 15i1fCD9BLVurrTuaN2boWoMX2urQd3CBe. That seems different from my usual.)

I clicked the add private key button and entered my private key.

> Private key saved for site signing.

The button changes to a message "Private key saved." And also now there is a link "FORGOT". Oh, so maybe there *is* a way to recover your private key if you forget or lose it?

![09zeroblog.clone.1papers.sidebar.4.key.png](img/09zeroblog.clone.1papers.sidebar.4.key.png)
+ *Sidebar, entering private key. [Full size](img/09zeroblog.clone.1papers.sidebar.4.key.png)*

### **10. Sign and Publish your new site.**

I clicked "Sign and Publish". At first no reaction, but then some messages appear.
> Content publish failed.

I've come to expect when creating a brand new zite. Basically it's because of the next message...

> No peers found, but your content is ready to access.

A brand new zite has no peers yet, hence the "Content publish failed" message. Once a few peers visit the site, that shouldn't be a problem any more.

![10zeroblog.clone.1papers.sidebar.5.png](img/10zeroblog.clone.1papers.sidebar.5.png)
+ *After signing & publishing. [Full size](img/10zeroblog.clone.1papers.sidebar.5.png)*


### **11. Reload your new site and start using it!**
At first I couldn't edit my new blog, but upon reload I could, and did a few basic things:
+ Changed blog title and description.
+ Made an ["About this blog"](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1Papers8S7fe6LEsa7BwVVywWVbMpUjgwx/?Post:1:About+this+blog) post.
+ Added link to the About post in the blog description.
+ Already automatically "Following" but only posts (which I already know about; I'm the one making the posts). So I also selected "Comments" to make sure I'm notified of those in my ZeroHello feed.

![11thepapersabout.png](img/11thepapersabout.png)
+ *Final result: about page with new blog with new address, following comments. [Full size](img/11thepapersabout.png)*

After doing the above steps and adding some content, I publicized the new site a few ways to get some peers for it. 
+ I made posts about it on my existing blogs and on ZeroMe.
+ I added it to a couple of "site promotion/directory sites", in my case [ZeroSites](http://127.0.0.1:43110/Sites.ZeroNetwork.bit/) and [ZeroCentral](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1Dt7FR5aNLkqAjmosWh8cMWzJu633GYN6u/). There are more ways, like [New 0Net Sites](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1LtvsjbtQ2tY7SCtCZzC4KhErqEK3bXD4n/) and getting your zite's address into a ZeroNet proxy like [0net.io](https://0net.io/) or [ZeroNet's Meta Proxy](https://zero.acelewis.com/).

## **Conclusion**
Well, that's how **I** ended up creating and using a vanity address, and it seems to be working. Let me know if I made any mistakes.

post.title: A rant ;) about intellectual property
post.body:
Today, the 26th of April, is World Intellectual Property Day. So I made a bit of a jokey post about it on ZeroMe.
+ [WIP Day post](http://127.0.0.1:43110/Me.ZeroNetwork.bit/?Post/12h51ug6CcntU2aiBjhP8Ns2e5VypbWWtv/131Seivv6aH8vnohPmYPcPwPfZ1a5ubMMs/1556287235)

That led to some comments there, including a bit of a rant ;) from me that I'd like to post here (with a few small tweaks & corrections), as it sort of sums up my views on the issue.

---
---

My main issue with copyrights & patents is not that they exist at all, but that certain lobbies have taken a short-term limitation ([14 years in the beginning](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Statute_of_Anne)) that was originally created by government for the public benefit (to encourage promulgation of knowledge, back when that was uncertain and expensive) and turned it into a near-eternal (e.g. author's life + 75 years!) private benefit for rent seekers* (in an era when we've never had less need for expensive publishers / gatekeepers / middlemen getting their cut), and have sold governments on the idea that copyrights & patents are all about "justice" for "creators", with the principle of public benefit completely hijacked (only what's good for the IP lobbies is good for the public, apparently).

`*` I say rent seekers and put "creators" in quotation marks because often IP doesn't really benefit the actual *creators* but instead companies who didn't create anything, like patent trolls, or companies whose business model is centred around screwing over an unending conveyor belt of young & naive hopefuls. E.g. record companies with plentiful lawyers & accountants and years of institutional experience who get teenage musicians who don't know any better to sign multi-year contracts handing over their copyrights and/or royalties until their "investment" in the artist has been paid off.

An example: De La Soul's 1989 album "*3 Feet High and Rising*" isn't on Spotify because the band is pissed off that their old record company wants to garnish the band's (already miniscule) royalties from it, claiming De La Soul still owe them money on it... 3 ***decades*** after it was released and sold millions of copies, earning the record company a fortune in the process. 
+ [BBC News - De La Soul's music was about to debut on streaming - then the band complained](https://www.bbc.com/news/entertainment-arts-47414260)

And if I remember correctly [The Return of the Jedi still hasn't technically made a profit, according to Lucasfilm's accountants](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hollywood_accounting). So no profit sharing for the actors.

In my humble opinion, trademarks are not as big a problem, as they don't seem to restrict the public from using / enjoying knowledge (books, music, medicines, inventions etc); as far as I can tell, they mainly just stop shitty businesses capitalizing on the marketing material (product names, logos, slogans, etc) of other businesses. But maybe there's a case against them too.

---

(And notice how IP lobbies' propaganda always talks about respecting "creators", glossing over the fact that, by definition, intellectual *property* benefits *proprietors*, not creators. Sometimes the owner of the copyright or patent and the creator/inventor of the work are the same person, but very often they are not.)

post.title: ZeroHello search & ZeroMe issues
post.body:
ZeroHello, the "start page" of ZeroNet, has a search box near the top, to look for content on:
+ any ZeroNet site you're connected to
+ a specific site, by adding the search query `site:sitename`

But I've noticed that when I do a general search there, it never returns results from ZeroMe. At least not from "official" ZeroMe, i.e. Me.ZeroNetwork.bit. But it does find ZeroMe posts through the alternative ZeroMe site/interface, Peeper.

I mentioned this in a comment on ZeroMe:
+ [Can anyone lists the advantages (and disadvantages, if any) / features of the alternative interfaces for ZeroMe:](http://127.0.0.1:43110/Me.ZeroNetwork.bit/?Post/12h51ug6CcntU2aiBjhP8Ns2e5VypbWWtv/131Seivv6aH8vnohPmYPcPwPfZ1a5ubMMs/1555700549)

And kxobot pointed out that ZeroHello search *can* find results from Me.ZeroNetwork.bit, but only if you search that site specifically.

For example, if I do a ZeroHello search for just "favicon", I will get results from Peeper, ZeroTalk, people's blogs etc. From all over ZeroNet *except* for Me.ZeroNetwork.bit.

However if I do a search for "favicon site:ZeroMe", I *do* get results from Me.ZeroNetwork.bit. The same results that it found on Peeper.

So that's odd. But it may seem irrelevant whether the results come from Peeper or Me.ZeroNetwork.bit. But often in the past, when I clicked on a result from Peeper, a Peeper page would open but the content (post, comments etc) would not appear. Now that I'm experimenting further, I realize the content does appear on Peeper pages, it just takes longer to show up than it does when I load a Me.ZeroNetwork.bit page.

Hopefully one day ZeroHello search will include results from Me.ZeroNetwork.bit among the rest.

post.title: Remember to follow your blog's comments
post.body:
I just remembered, thanks to only now noticing some week-old comments on my [media share blog](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1NEuAUKgUoY6fnXeXBaonjrDfNbfpQpdMp/?Home), that these ZeroBlogs (regular and MyZB both I think) will automatically follow *posts* on your blog (so you will see notifications of those in your ZeroHello feed) but not *comments*, so you will *not* receive notifications of those.

You have to remember to manually follow comments in order to receive notifications. In your blog's left-hand menu, click on the button that says "Follow" or "Following" and tick "Comments".

![ZeroBlog.follow.comments.8bit.png](img\ZeroBlog.follow.comments.8bit.png)

I also ticked "Username mentions" as well just in case, even though I don't really understand if it's necessary if "Comments" is ticked.

post.title: Experimenting with images: WebP
post.body: When experimenting with replacements for animated GIFs ( [part 1](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1Ctjcvfovq6d1JWEGvM1JovCym4H6Es33L/?Post:14:Experimenting+with+alternatives+to+GIFs,+part+1) & [part 2](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1Ctjcvfovq6d1JWEGvM1JovCym4H6Es33L/?Post:15:Experimenting+with+alternatives+to+GIFs,+part+2) ), I (re)discovered the WebP format. + [Wikipedia - WebP](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WebP) I looked into the animated version (like GIF), but it can also be used for still images, like JPG. There are claims it can make an image the same quality as JPG but with a file size up to 30% smaller. I wanted to post a link to an image in a ZeroMe thread. + I did a DuckDuckGo image search + found the image I wanted (an illustrated book cover for [*Stig of the Dump*](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stig_of_the_Dump) ) and saved it to my hard drive + uploaded it to ZeroUp Unlimited and then promptly realized "WTF?!?! ***647KB***! For that little JPG!?" Here it is: ![Stig - original JPG](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1CiXRY9ATZSoZqBzwMfXEMsKtPRt2aQoF2/data/users/131Seivv6aH8vnohPmYPcPwPfZ1a5ubMMs/1553882393-stig.revealed.jpg) ***[stig.revealed.jpg - 647KB](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1CiXRY9ATZSoZqBzwMfXEMsKtPRt2aQoF2/data/users/131Seivv6aH8vnohPmYPcPwPfZ1a5ubMMs/1553882393-stig.revealed.jpg)*** I opened the JPG in [Paint.net](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paint.net) to recompress it and hopefully reduce the file size a lot. I clicked "Save as..." and then adjusted the quality settings. Normally even just the default quality setting of 90 is enough to make a significant reduction in file size. Sometimes I take it down to 75. Only rarely, perhaps with a really large image-size, high-quality photograph do I take the quality setting down further, to maybe 60 or 50. Here's what happened with this JPG: |Qlty | File size | Note | | --- | --- | --- | | 90. | 632KB... | "Well that didn't do much!" | | 75. | 608KB... | "Nor that" | | 50. | 589KB... | At this point, I can hardly believe how little the file size is reducing | | 25. | 574KB... | "Seriously???" | | 0. | 553KB... | I have never taken the setting down all the way to zero on any file... and yet this damn (small) JPG is still over half a megabyte! | But just the other day I installed the [WebP plugin for Paint.net](https://forums.getpaint.net/topic/21773-webp-filetype-2019-01-25/), so I decided to give that a go. Here's what happened: |Qlty | File size | Note | | --- | --- | --- | | 90 | 84KB | "Damn! I didn't even need to do any special tweaks." |   ***[Paint.net - saving image as as WebP](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1CiXRY9ATZSoZqBzwMfXEMsKtPRt2aQoF2/data/users/131Seivv6aH8vnohPmYPcPwPfZ1a5ubMMs/1553886268-paint.saveas.webp)*** I looked and looked and at normal viewing size, I can barely tell the difference between the 647KB JPG and the 84KB WebP. The WebP is only ***13%*** the file size of the JPG. (Changing through the Presets like 'photo', 'drawing' etc barely made any difference in file size.) ![Stig - original JPG](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1CiXRY9ATZSoZqBzwMfXEMsKtPRt2aQoF2/data/users/131Seivv6aH8vnohPmYPcPwPfZ1a5ubMMs/1553882393-stig.revealed.jpg) ![Stig- WebP](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1CiXRY9ATZSoZqBzwMfXEMsKtPRt2aQoF2/data/users/131Seivv6aH8vnohPmYPcPwPfZ1a5ubMMs/1553882551-stig.revealed.webp) Left: [stig.revealed.jpg - 647KB](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1CiXRY9ATZSoZqBzwMfXEMsKtPRt2aQoF2/data/users/131Seivv6aH8vnohPmYPcPwPfZ1a5ubMMs/1553882393-stig.revealed.jpg) | Right: ***[stig.revealed.webp - 84KB](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1CiXRY9ATZSoZqBzwMfXEMsKtPRt2aQoF2/data/users/131Seivv6aH8vnohPmYPcPwPfZ1a5ubMMs/1553882551-stig.revealed.webp)*** ### **Conclusion** **Obviously this kind of saving wouldn't happen on every type of image, but it still seems we really should be using WebP instead of JPG, especially here on ZeroNet where we're trying to save bandwidth and storage space.** One issue with WebP compared to JPG. By default, in my browser (Vivaldi), if I click on the URL for a JPG, the image opens in the browser. But If I click on the URL for a WebP, the browser *downloads* it and then opens it in the default local viewer for that file type. **EDIT: Apparently this is an issue specific to how ZeroNet on Windows treats WebP, and an issue has been filed on Github. See [this post on ZeroTalk](http://127.0.0.1:43110/Talk.ZeroNetwork.bit/?Topic:1554160326_131Seivv6aH8vnohPmYPcPwPfZ1a5ubMMs).** *PS this is also my first experiment with markdown tables. Nice to have the feature but I wish the spacing & alignment were better. And side-by-side images too! Although I couldn't get the captions to align with the images using markdown table syntax.* *PPS I forgot that hotlinking images can be an issue on ZeroNet. Just because I can see the images hosted on ZeroUp Unlimited doesn't mean other people can. So I put a link to the source under each image. I've got to remember to be careful about that.*

post.title: .mhtml format for saving webpages
post.body: **.mhtml** is a format that saves an entire webpage's content (including images etc) in just one file. It's been around for years. I remember saving webpages in .mhtml back when I was on dial-up. It's also basically how e-mail messages can have fancy formatting, images etc. + [Wikipedia - MHTML](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MHTML) Just in case you got a security warning when getting any .mtml files I've shared, let me say it: **I'm not trying to harm your computer.** .Mhtml is just the easiest way I know to save and share webpages. If you're unsure, please scan the file with an anti-virus. I've been using .mhtml to save and repost the BBC's "The Papers" blog on my other blog [klu9's media share](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1NEuAUKgUoY6fnXeXBaonjrDfNbfpQpdMp/?Home), which has large images of UK newspapers' front pages, but only for one day. After that the BBC website deletes the images, for copyright issues I believe. You can compare the mhtml file I saved with the clearnet page from the BBC, from which all the images have already been removed. + [My .mhtml](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1CiXRY9ATZSoZqBzwMfXEMsKtPRt2aQoF2/data/users/131Seivv6aH8vnohPmYPcPwPfZ1a5ubMMs/UK.Newspapers.Front.Pages-2019.03.24.Sunday-BBC.News.(for.desktop%29.mhtml) + [BBC clearnet](https://www.bbc.com/news/blogs-the-papers-47688601) For me, I save the page as .mhtml in the Vivaldi browser. And when I open the file in the file manager, it opens in Vivaldi straight away. (Oddly, it also appears as a download in Vivaldi's download panel.) But when I open the .mhtml from within the browser (e.g. from posting it on ZeroNet), Vivaldi gives me a security warning about this file type and will only open it if I click "Keep". (Why is a webpage saved as .mhtml considered inherently dangerous? Why is it any more dangerous than a webpage served as .html calling in God-knows-what resources? Someone better qualified than me can maybe tell us why.) .mhtml been around for years, and browser support and treatment of the format has varied over the years. It seems it's not as easy and widely supported as it used to be. But I, as just a dumb user, have found no quicker & easier way to save and repost an entire webpage. I just click "Save Page as... MHTML" in my browser and then upload it to [ZeroUp Unlimited](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1CiXRY9ATZSoZqBzwMfXEMsKtPRt2aQoF2/) and that's it. I don't have to fiddle around creating folders in my zite, deal with HTML coding or wonder if key content (like images) will break/disappear. But as it seems there are issues with .mhtml nowadays, here I'll test it out a little in different browsers (on a Windows desktop): ### **Chrome** + Chrome does not open the link but treats it as a download. + It gives a warning message, saying this kind of file can harm your computer. + I can see no way within Chrome to open the .mhtml file in Chrome itself (it only offers to open it in my OS's default program for .mhtml, Vivaldi). + But if I right-click on the .mhtml file in the file manager, I can choose Chrome and it opens just fine. **Summary** Chrome can open .mhtml, but it will download it first, give you a security warning and, once you select "Keep", then you can open it in Chrome. ### **Firefox** (Quantum) + Firstly a brief ZeroNet error message pops up. > Connection with UiServer Websocket was lost. Reconnecting... + But after a couple of seconds it says > Connection with UiServer Websocket recovered. + Firefox does not open the link but treats it as a download. + It gives a dialog box to choose + + whether to open or save the file + + if to open it, what program to open with... and Firefox is not in the list of options. If I choose "Browse" and then find firefox.exe, it pause for a while and then sends me back through the whole "what do you want to do with this file" dialog box. + If I save the file, like Chrome, it will open in my default program, Vivaldi. + + But if I right-click on the .mhtml file in the file manager, Firefox is not in the list of available options. **Summary** Firefox Quantum (i.e. recent versions) treats .mhtml as a file to download, and refuses to open it all. ### **K-Meleon** K-Meleon is based on an older version of Firefox. + Just opening my 0net blog in K-Meleon gives those "websocket connection lost / recovered" messages. + those "websocket connection lost / recovered" messages happen again when I click the .mhtml link. + Just like Firefox, it gives a dialog box: "What should K-Meleon do with this file?" With one difference: K-Meleon is among the options to open the file with. + But if I try opening it with K-Meleon that way, it opens a blank tab and that dialog box comes up again. And if I again choose open with K-Meleon, a new blank tab and new dialog box open again. And that can go on and on. + The same happens if I try going through the file manager, right-clicking on the file and choosing Open wth... K-Meleon. Blank tab and a dialog box again. **Summary** K-Meleon treats .mhtml as a file to download, and makes you think it will open it but doesn't. ### **Safari** As if!!! ### **Internet Explorer** Is that still on my computer? What do you know, it is! + IE just opens the. mhtml as it would any other webpage. No dialog boxes, no security messages, no treating it as a download. It just plains opens it the way it's supposed to. **Summary** Internet Explorer just works! Who'd have believed it?! ## **Conclusion** So it looks like .mhtml is not ideal for serving a saved webpage to other people: their browser may not support it, and they may get spooked by security warnings. I just wish I knew of a way as easy as .mhtml for saving and reposting. (Another advantage: I just share it via an upload site like [ZeroUp Unlimited](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1CiXRY9ATZSoZqBzwMfXEMsKtPRt2aQoF2/), so it doesn't take away from my blog's limited space and I don't have to learn about things like optional files just yet.) Any (preferably easy) suggestions would appreciated. Perhaps even one that combines with the other thing I'd like to do, which is automate the process of saving The Papers blog article (on day of release, with images at maximum quality) and republishing it on ZeroNet. ### **What happens when *you* open an .mhtml file?** Let me know what happens for you, and what browser & operating system you're using.

post.title: Links with brackets in markdown and ZeroBlogs
post.body:
Sometimes you want to link to something that has brackets `(...)` in the URL or the file name.

E.g.
+ `https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Matrix_(protocol)`
+ `http://127.0.0.1:43110/1CiXRY9ATZSoZqBzwMfXEMsKtPRt2aQoF2/data/users/131Seivv6aH8vnohPmYPcPwPfZ1a5ubMMs/UK.Newspapers.Front.Pages-2019.03.24.Sunday-BBC.News.(for.desktop).mhtml`

But this can be problematic on ZeroNet: in several places (this blog here, ZeroMe) when I tried to post the link in [MarkDown](http://127.0.0.1:43110/138R53t3ZW7KDfSfxVpWUsMXgwUnsDNXLP/?Page:markdown) (the easy code for website formatting, used here on ZeroNet and elsewhere), the result was a broken link that **displayed** the closing bracket rather than making it part of the link.

E.g. If I wrote in markdown:
+ `[Matrix](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Matrix_(protocol))`

Then the page would show:
+ `Matrix)`

And the link would be:
+ `https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Matrix_(protocol`
without the closing bracket. So clicking it would result in an error page.

Fortunately @glightstar: found the solution:
+ [Percent-encoding](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Percent-encoding)

This is when you use `%` plus some numbers to represent certain characters to make sure the browser realizes it's part of the URL.

So to make sure links with brackets work, replace the URL's closing bracket `...)` (but not the markdown tag's closing bracket) with `%29`. E.g.:
+ `[Matrix](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Matrix_(protocol%29)`
+ `[UK.Newspapers.Front.Pages-2019.03.24.Sunday-BBC.News.(for.desktop).mhtml](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1CiXRY9ATZSoZqBzwMfXEMsKtPRt2aQoF2/data/users/131Seivv6aH8vnohPmYPcPwPfZ1a5ubMMs/UK.Newspapers.Front.Pages-2019.03.24.Sunday-BBC.News.(for.desktop%29.mhtml)`

And that should give you the properly displayed, properly working links below:
+ [Matrix](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Matrix_(protocol%29)
+ [UK.Newspapers.Front.Pages-2019.03.24.Sunday-BBC.News.(for.desktop).mhtml](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1CiXRY9ATZSoZqBzwMfXEMsKtPRt2aQoF2/data/users/131Seivv6aH8vnohPmYPcPwPfZ1a5ubMMs/UK.Newspapers.Front.Pages-2019.03.24.Sunday-BBC.News.(for.desktop%29.mhtml)

Note: this problem also happens when using the WYSIWYG editor in regular ZeroBlog to add a link with brackets, as I discovered when making [this post on klu9's media share](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1NEuAUKgUoY6fnXeXBaonjrDfNbfpQpdMp/?Post:4:UK+Newspapers+Front+Pages+-+Sunday+24th+March+2019). In the little popup box, make sure to replace the closing bracket with `%29`.

For some reason, it doesn't seem necessary to replace the *opening* bracket with percent-encoding.

post.title: Tags on My ZeroBlog
post.body:
I like the idea of tags for digital content like blogs (I know, I know: very 2000's of me). And, in contrast to regular *ZeroBlog*, *My ZeroBlog* (from which this blog is cloned) has tagging built in.

+ (See [this post](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1Ctjcvfovq6d1JWEGvM1JovCym4H6Es33L/?Post:13:This+is+not+a+ZeroBlog) for a little more on the issue of the difference between *ZeroBlog* and *My ZeroBlog*.)

So for fellow newbs, here are a few points I've noticed about tags on My ZeroBlog.

### **Tags don't need commas to separate**
**Just use spaces to separate tags.**
Out of habit from other blogging platforms, I put commas and spaces between tags, like so:
+ `0net, newb, blog`

But *My ZeroBlog* was treating the comma as part of the tag. I think that meant if the tag was the last in the list and had no comma after it (like "0net"), it would be treated as a different tag from one with a comma (like "0net,"). So once I realized the issue, I had to go back and clean out all the commas. So now when I put in several tags, it should be:
+ `0net newb blog`

### **Multi-word tags have to be done as one word**
+ The above point about spaces & commas means multi-word tags (like "social media") have to be done as one word (like `socialmedia`). Otherwise, your post will get tagged with `social` and also with `media`.

### **Tags are case-sensitive**
+ `P2P` and `p2p` are treated as different tags. So always keep the case consistent.
+ In the "[TOC by tag](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1Ctjcvfovq6d1JWEGvM1JovCym4H6Es33L/?Toc=tagAll)" (i.e. list of all tags on your blog), tags starting with uppercase letters are all listed above tags starting with lowercase letters. (At first glance I thought the list was not alphabetized... until I noticed it *is* alphabetized, but twice: first tags starting with uppercase listed alphabetically, then tags starting with lowercase listed alphabetically.)

![MyZeroBlog.tag.index.png](img/MyZeroBlog.tag.index.png)
+ [Full size](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1Ctjcvfovq6d1JWEGvM1JovCym4H6Es33L/img/MyZeroBlog.tag.index.png)
+ My tag index, after I'd cleaned up some things but before cleaning up others. Note the dual alphabetization (first uppercase, then lowercase) and case distinction (`P2P` and `p2p` are treated as different tags).

### **Sometimes tags appear replicated**
Every now and then when I'm working on and viewing this blog, a post's tags seem to multiply and replicate. (At least for me, I don't know if that happens to visitors.)

![MyZeroBlog.tag.overload.png](img/MyZeroBlog.tag.overload.png)
+ [Full size](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1Ctjcvfovq6d1JWEGvM1JovCym4H6Es33L/img/MyZeroBlog.tag.overload.png)

But don't worry: it's just a temporary effect that disappears when you refresh the page :)

post.title: Getting more space on ZeroTalk
post.body:
Sites on ZeroNet that allow other people to do things (like make posts, comments, upvotes etc) have a limit on the space they allow users for that content and activity (to prevent spamming).

[ZeroTalk](http://127.0.0.1:43110/Talk.ZeroNetwork.bit/), the principal forum on ZeroNet, by default allows new users just 100KB. You can see how much space you've used up just below the comment box, saying something like `USED: 80.7K/100K`.

When you get close to that limit, a message will appear there telling you to contact **nofish** (the admin of ZeroTalk and the creator of ZeroNet itself) to request an increase. His name links to his [ZeroMail](http://127.0.0.1:43110/Mail.ZeroNetwork.bit/) address.

![ZeroTalk - running out of space.png](img/ZeroTalk-running.out.of.space.png)
[Full size image](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1Ctjcvfovq6d1JWEGvM1JovCym4H6Es33L/img/ZeroTalk-running.out.of.space.png)

**But don't use ZeroMail: it won't work.** (It didn't for me, at least.) Instead use [ZeroMe](http://127.0.0.1:43110/Me.ZeroNetwork.bit/). Write a request there mentioning him and make sure you format his name with `@` and `:` before and after, so that the message will appear in his [ZeroHello](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1HeLLo4uzjaLetFx6NH3PMwFP3qbRbTf3D/) notifications feed.

E.g.
> [**@nofish:** Please raise my limit on Zerotalk. Thanks.](http://127.0.0.1:43110/Me.ZeroNetwork.bit/?Post/12h51ug6CcntU2aiBjhP8Ns2e5VypbWWtv/131Seivv6aH8vnohPmYPcPwPfZ1a5ubMMs/1553203658)

Using ZeroMail, I still had no response or increase in space limit after 12 days. But within 1 day of doing it via ZeroMe, I didn't get a response but my limit was raised. To 200KB.

So I guess I'll be having to do this again in another few months :)

post.title: Experimenting with alternatives to GIFs, part 2
post.body:
In [Part 1](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1Ctjcvfovq6d1JWEGvM1JovCym4H6Es33L/?Post:14:Experimenting+with+alternatives+to+GIFs,+part+1), I posted a brief experiment making and comparing (the file size at least) alternatives to animated GIFs. Part 2 is about getting these image & video formats to display on a ZeroBlog, and to do so in a way just like animated GIFs, i.e.
+ Displays automatically
+ Plays automatically
+ Loops automatically
+ No control bar obscuring part of the image

----

Because this blog here is not a regular ZeroBlog, I cloned ZeroBlog to create a sandbox for experimenting. It's here:
+ [klu9's ZeroBlog sandbox](http://127.0.0.1:43110/15mQd6kBRzriaVEjdELujex2YKFfWaA8JQ/?Home) (it might be a while before there are other peers in order to view the zite)

----

I'll summarize the results so far here.

**Key:**
+ **WYSIWYG**: Using ZeroBlog's WYSIWYG editing mode to insert the file into the blog post (ZeroBlog's editing mode automatically taking care of copying the file to the right folder and then inserting into the blog post the code to display it).
+ **Manual**: The blogger manually copying the file to the right folder and then manually writing and inserting the code (either Markdown or HTML) to display it.

### **Animated GIF** (1.97MB)
+ WYSIWYG: **Failure**. Converted to still JPG.
+ Manual: **Success**. Using markdown code.
+ [View post](http://127.0.0.1:43110/15mQd6kBRzriaVEjdELujex2YKFfWaA8JQ/?Post:3:Manually+inserting+a+GIF+into+a+ZeroBlog+post)

### **Animated PNG** (1.57MB)
+ WYSIWYG: **Failure**. Converted to still JPG.
+ Manual: **Success**. Using markdown code.
+ [View post](http://127.0.0.1:43110/15mQd6kBRzriaVEjdELujex2YKFfWaA8JQ/?Post:4:Inserting+an+Animated+PNG+into+a+ZeroBlog)

### **Animated WebP** (280KB)
+ WYSIWYG: **Failure**. Converted to still **WebP**.
+ Manual: **Success**. Using markdown code.
+ [View post](http://127.0.0.1:43110/15mQd6kBRzriaVEjdELujex2YKFfWaA8JQ/?Post:5:Inserting+an+animated+WebP+into+a+ZeroBlog+post)

### **MP4** (324KB)
+ WYSIWYG: No "Insert video" option.
+ Manual: Success... apparently... at first. Upon reload, **Failure**. It displays a still image. In order to play, the user has to right-click on the still image, select "Show controls" and then press play. Using HTML code.
+ [View post](http://127.0.0.1:43110/15mQd6kBRzriaVEjdELujex2YKFfWaA8JQ/?Post:6:Inserting+an+MP4+into+a+ZeroBlog+post)

### **WebM** (113KB)
+ WYSIWYG: No "Insert video" option.
+ Manual: **Failure**. Using HTML code. Just a big empty space. The HTML code keeps getting modified somehow.
+ [View post](http://127.0.0.1:43110/15mQd6kBRzriaVEjdELujex2YKFfWaA8JQ/?Post:7:Inserting+a+WebM+into+a+ZeroBlog+post)

## **Conclusion**
So while WebM is the smallest file size, I can't make it work on a ZeroBlog. MP4 appears to work at first, but upon reload is a failure (on 3 out of 4 criteria).

Also, even if I could get videos working on ZeroBlog, they might get blocked by browser extensions or settings that prevent autoplaying video.

So at the moment, I'm favouring lossy WebP, which:
+ works (manually at least)
+ gives a small file size (smaller than MP4)
+ can be inserted with markdown code (rather than HTML)
+ won't be blocked by video autoplay blocking methods

(I might also try out posting these formats on other ZeroNet platforms, e.g. MyZeroBlog {like this blog here} or even cloning [GifTime](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1Gif7PqWTzVWDQ42Mo7np3zXmGAo3DXc7h). After all, it's got "Gif" in the name, and it publishes mp4s).

post.title: Experimenting with alternatives to GIFs, part 1
post.body:
As we all know, [GIFs are evil](http://127.0.0.1:43110/Me.ZeroNetwork.bit/?Post/1SunAWK2VUT9GQK32MpwRfFPVgcBSJN9a/16dEowtNbV89NxPcDrAKkmnuXtiJVoVcDm/1550063744). :)

Apart from issues like frame rate and limited colours, the main problem for us ZeroNet users is size: animated GIFs can easily have file sizes measuring in multiple megabytes. That's a problem when ZeroNet is based on ordinary users giving up their own disk space, bandwidth and data allowances to host and share everyone's zites.

But animated GIFs are ***fun!!!*** They automatically display, and move, and loop. All with no annoying sound! How to have all the fun of animated GIFs without all the bloat?

+ **Here in part 1**, I'll briefly check out some alternatives to GIFs, and how to make them. **In part 2**, I'll discuss trying to get these moving image formats to display in a blog on ZeroNet.

## The GIFs
I recently made [a post on my ZeroBlog "klu9's media share" about a comedy movie](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1NEuAUKgUoY6fnXeXBaonjrDfNbfpQpdMp/?Post:3:Monty+Python's+The+Meaning+of+Life). A great opportunity for some funny moving images!

I found a couple of animated GIFs online I wanted to include in my post. But the file sizes were rather large: one was 543KB, the other 1.97MB. With only a few more posts like that, my blog would very quickly use up its default 10MB of space allowed on other users' hard drives and would start nagging people with "Set Limit to {X]MB" messages.

Here are the original GIFs, shared on ZeroUp Unlimited to avoid using up my zite's 10MB.
+ [Monty.death.gif - 543KB](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1CiXRY9ATZSoZqBzwMfXEMsKtPRt2aQoF2/data/users/131Seivv6aH8vnohPmYPcPwPfZ1a5ubMMs/1552758773-monty.death.gif)
+ [Monty.Python.Every.Sperm.is.Sacred.gif - 1.97MB](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1CiXRY9ATZSoZqBzwMfXEMsKtPRt2aQoF2/data/users/131Seivv6aH8vnohPmYPcPwPfZ1a5ubMMs/Monty.Python.Every.Sperm.Is.Sacred--OriginalGIF.gif)

## The Alternatives
Over the years, I'd heard of alternatives to GIFs, mainly video formats like .mp4 and .webm. (After all, what is an animated GIF but a form of short video?) Online image hosts like [imgur](https://www.imgur.com/) and [giphy](https://www.giphy.com/) automatically convert animated GIFs to video formats to save space and data traffic.
+ [Wikipedia - Video alternative to GIF](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Video_alternative_to_GIF)
+ [Wikipedia - MP4](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MPEG-4_Part_14)
+ [Wikipedia - WebM](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Webm)

There are also formats originally designed for still images but which also have animated forms too: PNG and WebP.
+ [Wikipedia - PNG](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Portable_Network_Graphics)
+ [Wikipedia - WebP](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WebP)

First off, I thought I'd try converting the desired GIFs to WebM. There are command-line tools that can do this kind of conversion, like the Swiss Army Knife of video that is [FFmpeg](https://ffmpeg.org/). But I'm a bit command-line phobic so I searched for a more GUI-fied option.

There are plenty of [online converters](https://duckduckgo.com/?q=convert+gif), where you upload the GIF to a website, it converts it and then you download/save it back to your hard drive. That's probably the easiest option for just one or two GIFs.

There are also offline programs you can use on your computer, which often have the ability to convert whole batches of files. As I have a bunch of GIFs saved on my hard drive that I eventually want to convert, I've decided to investigate both options.

### WebM
Some DuckDuckGoing led me to [WebMConverter, a.k.a. WebM for Retards](https://gitgud.io/nixx/WebMConverter). Surely that'll be simple enough even for me! I downloaded, unzipped and ran it, at which point it told me it needed some other software called Avisynth and promptly opened [a webpage to download it](http://avisynth.nl/index.php/Main_Page#Official_builds). After getting lost trying to find a 64-bit installer, I just went with [the first link for 32-bit](http://sourceforge.net/projects/avisynth2/).

Once Avisynth was installed, I could run WebMConverter. I chose the 543KB GIF (monty.death.gif) as the Input file.

There are a few tabs and a heck of a lot of options available in WebMConverter but I only changed one setting: in the **Encoding** tab > **General**, I changed from **Constant** to **Variable**. I did this because of the easy-to-understand explanations.
> **Constant** - This will make your video have a specific file size, and suffer low quality to match that size.
> **Variable** - This will make your video get the size it deserves to look good.

![WebMConverter](img\WebMConverter.png)
[Full size](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1Ctjcvfovq6d1JWEGvM1JovCym4H6Es33L/img/WebMConverter.png)

Once that was done, I clicked **Convert**. In just a second or two the job was done and I clicked WebMConverter's **Play** button to see the result. It was good. Then I went to check the file size... 16KB! Whoa!!! It reduced the file size by a factor of **33**!!!

Here's the result on ZeroUp Unlimited:
+ [monty.death.webm - 16KB](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1CiXRY9ATZSoZqBzwMfXEMsKtPRt2aQoF2/data/users/131Seivv6aH8vnohPmYPcPwPfZ1a5ubMMs/1552759261-monty.death.webm)

I did the same with the 1.97MB GIF (every.sperm.is.sacred.gif), a more complicated image, and WebMConverter produced a video that was only 113KB. A reduction by a factor of *only* about 20; still great!

### The Others: MP4, PNG, WebP
Later I went ahead and also converted that larger GIF to MP4, animated PNG, and animated WebP for comparison.

+ For MP4, I uploaded the GIF to [giphy](https://giphy.com). Once the [GIF's hosting page](https://giphy.com/gifs/EqOc3PnWWaXNja2rVw) was displayed, I clicked on "Media" to the right of the image, which led to an [MP4 page](https://media.giphy.com/media/EqOc3PnWWaXNja2rVw/giphy.mp4). (For some reason I couldn't do anything with it there but I was able to right-click on it, open in a new tab and then save it.)
+ For animated PNG, I used a GUI tool called [gif2apng_gui](http://gif2apng.sourceforge.net/).
+ For animated WebP, I used an online converter, [ezgif.com](https://ezgif.com/gif-to-webp) and chose the option "Lossy" in order to get a smaller file size.

## The Results
Here are all five versions of the larger file (every.sperm.is.sacred) shared on ZeroUp Unlimited:
+ [Source GIF: 1.97MB](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1CiXRY9ATZSoZqBzwMfXEMsKtPRt2aQoF2/data/users/131Seivv6aH8vnohPmYPcPwPfZ1a5ubMMs/Monty.Python.Every.Sperm.Is.Sacred--OriginalGIF.gif)
+ [Animated PNG: 1.57MB](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1CiXRY9ATZSoZqBzwMfXEMsKtPRt2aQoF2/data/users/131Seivv6aH8vnohPmYPcPwPfZ1a5ubMMs/Monty.Python.Every.Sperm.Is.Sacred--Animated.PNG.png)
+ [MP4: 324KB](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1CiXRY9ATZSoZqBzwMfXEMsKtPRt2aQoF2/data/users/131Seivv6aH8vnohPmYPcPwPfZ1a5ubMMs/Monty.Python.Every.Sperm.Is.Sacred--MP4.mp4)
+ [WebP (lossy): 280KB](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1CiXRY9ATZSoZqBzwMfXEMsKtPRt2aQoF2/data/users/131Seivv6aH8vnohPmYPcPwPfZ1a5ubMMs/Monty.Python.Every.Sperm.Is.Sacred--AnimatedWEBP.webp)
+ [WebM: 113KB](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1CiXRY9ATZSoZqBzwMfXEMsKtPRt2aQoF2/data/users/131Seivv6aH8vnohPmYPcPwPfZ1a5ubMMs/Monty.Python.Every.Sperm.Is.Sacred--WEBM.webm)

Remember when comparing the quality:
+ I am not an expert on any of these formats or converting between them. I did little or no tweaking of options.
+ The starting point were GIFs I found online. You'd probably get better results starting from the original video.

## The Conclusion
So it looks like WebM is the best alternative to animated GIF, at least when it comes to file size.

In part 2, I'll look at the next step: getting the image/video into a blog post.

post.title: This is not a ZeroBlog
post.body:
When I first got started on ZeroNet, I saw quite a few "new and improved" claims about zites (better, more features etc). At that point I cloned [MyZeroBlog](http://127.0.0.1:43110/19k2nhubaYsDJNPHL6iNs3D2K9Mgj66P4R/), based on such claims.

But then after a few more days I realized a lot of claims were unsupported by evidence or just plain out of date. So I wanted to see if it was possible to change to [regular ZeroBlog](http://127.0.0.1:43110/Blog.ZeroNetwork.bit/), as it was clearly receiving regular maintenance and updates. I couldn't really tell if anyone had improved MyZeroBlog since 2016.

I started a topic on ZeroTalk, [**I cloned one blog, can I change to a different one?**](http://127.0.0.1:43110/Talk.ZeroNetwork.bit/?Topic:1546099537_131Seivv6aH8vnohPmYPcPwPfZ1a5ubMMs), and followed some advice there.

I thought it had worked, basically because the blog didn't die and the two formats are so similar. But [now that I've started another blog](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1NEuAUKgUoY6fnXeXBaonjrDfNbfpQpdMp/?Home), cloned directly from ZeroBlog, I realize whatever it was I tried did **not** change this blog here from MyZeroBlog to regular ZeroBlog. I now realize it's still a MyZeroBlog.

And that explains why, when I'm editing a post, I don't get the blue circle giving a WYSIWYG editor & functions that @Geekless: mentioned, allowing image upload and enlarging, an issue I lamented in my post [Experimenting with uploads: images](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1Ctjcvfovq6d1JWEGvM1JovCym4H6Es33L/?Post:4:Experimenting+with+uploads:+images). I have to do it all manually, dropping files into the **/img** folder and then making a link for the full size image.

On the other hand, MyZeroBlog *does* allow tagging. There are probably other differences too.

Now that I'm invested in this blog here (my bad), **does anyone know of a way to add the WYSIWYG editor to a MyZeroBlog?** Or at least the image upload and enlargement function?

Any help appreciated.

post.title: Build a database of media metadata on ZeroNet
post.body:
I'm posting here an unfinished draft of an article that got ***way*** too big and for which I was way underqualified. But the issue came up in a ZeroTalk thread:
+ [movie hash collaborative site possible ?](http://127.0.0.1:43110/Talk.ZeroNetwork.bit/?Topic:1551558721_1CVzc6Q13qL6MskGL9Ni7os6GjforTAHmb/movie+hash+collaborative+site+possible)

That thread gives the gist of it, and my post was becoming too much about idea #2 (importing Bitzi Bitpedia database, which I realized probably wasn't useful, what with most people nowadays preferring high definition x264/x265 encodes rather than DivX .avi's). So as I'm probably never going to get round to completing this article (research, corrections, screenshots, links, cutting it ***way*** down), I'll throw the draft in here in case anyone's interested.

I've put the unfinished bits in `code` style.

---
# Short version
What do you think about:
1. a program that makes it easier to submit media file metadata (and perhaps the files themselves) to a searchable, browseable database from which people could download the files, either via p2p like BitTorrent / ed2k / G2 or through ZeroNet itself, perhaps in combination with IPFS
2. kickstarting that database with a Bitzi datadump 

# Long version:
Anyone remember **Bitzi**? They were the folks who gave us **Magnet URIs**, those strings of letters & numbers, often presented as just a clickable image of an old-fashioned horseshoe magnet, that will get your download client (usually a BitTorrent client nowadays) to start looking for and downloading a file.

`Magnet URI image`
`plain text magnet URI`

(A URI isn't a link to a *location* like an URL, a place where a file is located. Instead it's an *ID* for a file, and will try to get the file with that ID no matter where it's located, for example on any of the computers participating in a peer-to-peer file sharing network. A URI is an example of metadata, information about a file.)

### Bitzi, Bitpedia, Bitcollider

Bitzi invented Magnet URIs *and* had an online database of file checksums & Magnet URIs that users could contribute to,  and the database was published with a Creative Commons licence. They offered their own tool, **Bitcollider**, to make it easy to hash files, produce checksums and upload the Magnet URIs to their site. Just drag files onto Bitcollider and it would hash them and open up their site, Bitzi's **Bitpedia**, in your browser to paste & submit the metadata for the files. Things like file size, resolution, bitrate, as well as hashes / checksums. It would provide Magnets with Tiger Tree & SHA1 hashes as well as other hashes for several p2p filesharing systems, e.g. ed2k hashes for eDonkey 2000 & eMule.

In addition to submitting metadata & Magnets, visitors to the site could browse and search among existing metadata. When they found a file they were interested in, they could see a few details (file name, size, checksum etc) and if they wanted the file, they could just click on the Magnet URI, their preferred download program would open and it would (hopefully, depending on available sources) start downloading.

(A hash or checksum is a way of uniquely identifying a computer file. The file is run through a mathematical process/formula (it is hashed) and results in a string of numbers and letters that is unique and which no other computer file can produce. That at least is the hope; some formulas are better, while others can produce the same checksum (called a "collision") for two different files if there are only small differences. Famous examples of good hashing methods are SHA1, Tiger Tree and MD5. A Magnet URI can contain one or more different hashes.)

### The Demise of Bitpedia

While I submitted many hashes there back when I was mostly using Kazaa Lite and eMule, unfortunately the site slowly died and finally closed in 2013 (by which time I'd sort of forgotten about it, as I was spending my filesharing time on dedicated p2p websites and indexers with fancy extra stuff like commenting, forums, screenshots etc... you know, exactly the kind of site that gets taken down by legal action & intimidation on a regular basis). 

There must have been drawbacks compared to the likes of forums such as Sharereactor (for the ed2k & kad networks), FastTrack Central (for the FastTrack network of KaZaA, Grokster etc) and The Pirate Bay (for BitTorrent), but it's been so long (and the Wayback Machine doesn't replicate enough of the experience) that I can't remember. 

One thing was that it wasn't very "sticky": it was transactional: submit or get a magnet and leave. No real sense of community or forums.

But I suspect the biggest reason was because (I believe, I'm not sure) BitTorrent became so dominant, and BT cares about more than just the file ID (unlike the other p2p systems common in the 00's) but also the tracker, folder contents & location etc, leading to "fragmentation". With BitTorrent you need a magnet of the **entire torrent**, not just a file on its own. (The torrent is the little file ending in *.torrent* that contains information about the file you really want to get.) A magnet for a torrent is data about data about data: so it's not metadata, it's meta-metadata. A file-only magnet ("plain", "neutral", "universal"), simple metadata, would work with KaZaA or eMule or others but wouldn't with BT. And magnets for .torrents of files would not work for other p2p apps and not work for other (e.g. private) trackers. Please correct me if I'm wrong.

`META: Give example workflow of each.`
`+++ A magnet of an avi. Pure and simple. Works with anything... except BitTorrent.`
`+++ A magnet of a torrent of an avi (perhaps its folder, maybe an .nfo file in the same folder, and probably also the tracker for finding and connecting to peers with those files). Works with nothing except BitTorrent and the right tracker if you can access it (e.g. either it's public or it's a private one that you're a member of). Torrent magnets might place the tracker details directly into the magnet. E.g. !!!`

Bitpedia had to have a separate field from the regular "universal" file-only magnet for "Torrent download" and it was often empty. (And in theory, it would have had to have a different magnet link for every single instance of a torrent of that file, as every little difference in folder, tracker etc would mean a different .torrent file and thus a different checksum; the other p2p apps were satisfied with just one single universal file identifier.) Whereas other sites like The Pirate Bay, Suprnova etc were dedicated to BitTorrent and their .torrent files (and later magnets of .torrents) had all those extra details necessary for a successful bittorrent download. 

So I think as other apps declined and BitTorrent rose, Bitpedia became useful to fewer and fewer people.

Interestingly, unlike other sites with magnets of copyrighted material that shut down, I don't think any legal threats or action were behind the demise of Bitpedia. That may or may not be relevant to running a media database zite on ZeroNet.

### Database, datadumps, new beginning on ZeroNet?

But Bitpedia did have loads and loads of "universal" file-only checksums & magnets. And apparently they offered full datadumps (download of their entire database).

Here's one: https://old.datahub.io/dataset/bitzi

Any new filesharing database needs to attract users, but users won't spend long on a media database that's practically empty: "I can't find anything I want here. I'm leaving!" And thus they won't stick around to make their own contributions to the database, leaving it empty. (A bit like ZeroTorrent ;) It's a bit of a chicken and egg situation. But a Bitzi Bitpedia datadump could be a handy way to populate/kick start a metadata database on ZeroNet.

+ http://web.archive.org/web/20131209222254/http://bitzi.com/bitpedia/
+ http://web.archive.org/web/20091211184946/http://bitzi.com:80/stat/bitprints_week_100
+ http://web.archive.org/web/20080605233412/http://bitzi.com:80/stat/tag


### Example
I used the magnet from [this Bitpedia page on the Internet Archive](http://web.archive.org/web/20130913032141/http://bitzi.com:80/lookup/ADE2HDOI75PZB2NR6CVB7BEJJL4C37TW
) and:
+ Good news: The file *Transformers[2007]DvDrip[Eng]-aXXo.avi* started downloading almost immediately, so this data still works!
+ Bad news: The file *Transformers[2007]DvDrip[Eng]-aXXo.avi* started downloading almost immediately, so... I'm getting a really crappy movie! :)

Here's the [magnet](magnet:/?xt=urn:sha1:ADE2HDOI75PZB2NR6CVB7BEJJL4C37TW&xt=urn:kzhash:0641b44dd39435abdeaf3d079fe335aa4106a6d44f3a48aa7c84eae954db204333443956&xt=urn:tree:tiger:ULG2BHO3HFK4KVQQA5D42QBIRFU6CRPOFMNG6UY&xt=urn:ed2k:f921df1c57b2011f795f245c94ce70da&xl=943955968&dn=Transformers[2007]DvDrip[Eng]-aXXo.avi).

However it should be noted it didn't work with uTorrent, which just gave an error "Couldn't parse Magnet URI". It did work with Shareaza, which found a source on its own G2 (Gnutella 2) p2p filesharing network. (also the magnets on the Magnet URI sourceforge page??)

`META: find and compare with torrent and torrent magnet from torrent indexer for same file.`


### Age of Metadata
Obviously a Bitpedia datadump won't have metadata for any media produced after 2013, or any new digital versions since then (e.g. another rip in a new codec or file format). But it would still have it for lots of stuff from before 2013 that people would stll be interested in. And don't forget: that older stuff might never be released in a newer format. So many things released on VHS never made it to DVD, and so many things on DVD have never made it to Blu Ray or streaming. So while someone looking for Transformers might not be happy finding a result in standard definition .avi, there are so many other files people will be looking for that they'll be glad to find any working result.

**And perhaps the data dump could be run through a program that checks to see if a file still has sources on some tracker or p2p network or on ZeroNet. Any without sources could be excluded from upload to a new public ZeroNet database.** (PS the more I think about this, the more necessary it seems; people would get pissed off if 99% of the files in the database had no sources.)

### Why not just scrape a torrent site?
That could be one useful option, especially if it's to populate a public-tracker-BitTorrent-exclusive database, like [ZeroTorrent](http://127.0.0.1:43110/ZeroTorrent.bit/). But the torrent magnets /checksums are magnets/checksums of torrents, not the files themselves (if I've understood correctly). You're not getting metadata about the files but about the .torrent for the files. So they wouldn't be useful for any form of filesharing other than BitTorrent, unlike the "universal" magnets and checksums of Bitpedia.

From what I've read so far, ZeroNet distributes data based on BitTorrent but doesn't interact with & download from non-ZeroNet trackers. So a torrent-specific magnet / checksum wouldn't be able to get the file over ZeroNet, nor split/swarm the download from multiple sources across public torrent trackers and ZeroNet. Whereas Bitpedia's "universal" file-only checksums and magnets could be useful for getting files within ZeroNet, IPFS, `(I2P?), (ed2k?), (Kad?),` Gnutella, G2, `(DC++?)`, HTTP and so on and even systems not yet invented (I believe, I'm not technically expert on this.)
* `(I believe there's an eMule mod specifically for I2P.)`
* `(I believe eMule can't handle a magnet unless it specifically includes an ed2k hash because that's all the ed2k networkwas designed to transmit. Gnutella & G2, and probably others too, are satisfied with the magnet just having generic hashes like SHA1 and Tiger Tree.)`

Also, torrents are for Christmas, other networks are for life! :) What I mean is media files shared via BitTorrent (with their fragmentation across different .torrent files, trackers public and private etc) are often great for a short time but then reach a point of no seeds relatively soon.

Whereas files through other filesharing systems can still be found years later, even if they are slower. Remember my example above: a six-year-old magnet for an 12-year old movie? No problem for non-BT. That's especially useful for rarer files. `((In fact I think the BT client BitComet tries to overcome .torrent demise with its own unique techniques.))` E.g. I tried to get a TV series  broadcast once and never released on DVD. Through BitTorrent, it was "0 seeds" only a few months after broadcast. Every tracker and site I could find. I even clicked the torrent magnets any way and let them run in my client for a few weeks: always 0 seeds, 0kb downloaded. Eventually I turned to eMule and got all the episodes there without fail. (Of course, it took ***months*** to get those rare files, but at least I got them.)

### Something like Bitpedia & Bitcollider but for ZeroNet
I think it could be great to have something like the Bitcollider combined with `(ZeroNet // ZeroNet plus IPFS?)`. Just drop a file onto the app, it hashes the file and it opens a submission window with a lot of key details already there (obviously checksum, size, name but also details like resolution, codec etc) and then click, you've submitted it to a ZeroNet database or filesharing hub. Easy!

Hey, Bitcollider was open source! I wonder how easy it would be to modify it for a working site/zite?

`Could it be Metalinks links instead, combining regular P2P, ZeroNet, clearweb HTTP, IPFS etc?`

## What do you think? Please comment.

PS I wonder... if magnet URIs had been invented a year or two earlier, would we ever have had .torrent files? Or would BitTorrent have used magnets from the start and just download based on nothing more than the direct file-only metadata and we wouldn't have had this issue at all?

post.title: Interview with Rabble re Twitter, IndyMedia, Secure Scuttlebutt
post.body:
Here's a two-part interview with Evan Henshaw-Plath (a.k.a. Rabble, a.k.a. "Twitter employee #1") and who is now involved with the decentralized platform (/ZeroNet competitor?) [Secure Scuttlebutt](https://www.scuttlebutt.nz/).

It's from [*Steal This Show*](https://stealthisshow.com/), a podcast about P2P, decentralization, copyright issues etc, made by [Jamie King](), the director of [*Steal This Film*](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Steal_This_Film) about The Pirate Bay. Steal This Show is released via filesharing news site [TorrentFreak](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1JNqdTGVATFWRLzzYwVu19CuWYus5VmoUS/)

### Steal This Show - 2019-02-05 - Software will Eat the World, with @Rabble - Part 1
<audio controls>
    <source src="http://127.0.0.1:43110/1MzV32sv55VSD5Vr7u3mcMPsX2oG9PHusr/data/users/131Seivv6aH8vnohPmYPcPwPfZ1a5ubMMs/Steal-This-Show--2019-02-05--software-eats-the-world-part-1-with-rabble.mp3" type="audio/mpeg">
Your browser does not support the audio element.
</audio>
+ [IFS page for this audio](http://127.0.0.1:43110/12MVkvYGcRW6u2NYbpfwVad1oQeyG4s9Er/index.html?view:item+id:1Mz1_131Seivv6aH8vnohPmYPcPwPfZ1a5ubMMs_item_1+type:audio) (click this if the embedded player doesn't work for you)
+ [Clearnet source](https://stealthisshow.com/s04e11/)

### Steal This Show - 2019-03-01 - Software will Eat the World, with @Rabble - Part 2
<audio controls>
    <source src="http://127.0.0.1:43110/1MzV32sv55VSD5Vr7u3mcMPsX2oG9PHusr/data/users/131Seivv6aH8vnohPmYPcPwPfZ1a5ubMMs/Steal-This-Show--2019-03-01--software-eats-the-world-part-2-with-rabble.mp3" type="audio/mpeg">
Your browser does not support the audio element.
</audio>
+ [IFS page for this audio](http://127.0.0.1:43110/12MVkvYGcRW6u2NYbpfwVad1oQeyG4s9Er/index.html?view:item+id:1Mz1_131Seivv6aH8vnohPmYPcPwPfZ1a5ubMMs_item_2+type:audio) (click this if the embedded player doesn't work for you)
+ [Clearnet source](https://stealthisshow.com/s04e12/)

### Description:
> a two-part interview with [@Rabble](https://about.me/rabble) (Evan Henshaw-Plath) — activist technologist, co-founder of [IndyMedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Independent_Media_Center), and one of the originators of Twitter. We discuss the origins of Twitter in the protest organisation tool [TxtMob](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/TXTMob); Evan’s work developing Indymedia and the early days of tech’s interaction with activism; how social media is continuing to mutate politics, for better and worse; how the sorting algorithms developed by Big Social are becoming indelibly embedded in our world — and finally Evan introduces the subject of part two: Silicon Valley’s hidden mission to restructure the world’s institutions via software.

---
It's a fascinating interview, offering firsthand insights into the odd mishmash of 1960s & 70s social and cultural values of northern California that are encoded in the DNA of Silicon Valley tech companies and which as a result shapes the lives of everyone around the world today affected by those platforms.

In part 2, they go more into decentralization and federation, what attracted Rabble to Secure Scuttlebutt, his finally getting getting involved in its development, and the challenges involved in making it scalable, sustainable (through enabling encryption of content that only paid subscribers can access) and tolerable (through federating and segregating: *we don't want to connect to neonazis, they don't want to connect to us, but we can both get on our with own thing among our own friends*).

I am not a lefty (so parts of this were not easy listening for me), but Henshaw-Plath is clearly a clever and eloquent person with a lot of experience in these fields and a lot of interesting things to say on these topics. (The interviewer King does go on sometimes with his own less interesting thoughts.)

More on Henshaw-Plath: [Al Jazeera - Rebel Geeks - Steal from the Capitalists](https://www.aljazeera.com/programmes/rebelgeeks/2015/11/technology-steal-capitalists-151110150718814.html)

Let me know in the comments what you think (and if the embedded audio worked for you).

post.title: Experimenting with uploads: audio
post.body:
Here I'm going to upload some audio files to [IFS](http://127.0.0.1:43110/12MVkvYGcRW6u2NYbpfwVad1oQeyG4s9Er) (the "Intergalactic File Server", a zite for uploading, storing, finding, and playing many kinds of files) and then try to embed them in this blog post here.

## Part 1: Uploading to IFS

If you are new to IFS, it can be a little unclear how to upload stuff there. There is no nice, obvious "Upload" button like on other sites, e.g. video zite [KopyKate](http://127.0.0.1:43110/big.kopykate.bit/). (There is also no help or info on IFS about what the zite is or how to use it!) From an old ZeroTalk thread (IIRC), I found out you have to create a "channel" first, then upload to your channel.

(Some of the info here may be incomplete because some time has passed between me first going to IFS, and me writing this post.)

![IFS - ID menu](img\IFS.my.menu.png)

1. Go to [IFS](http://127.0.0.1:43110/12MVkvYGcRW6u2NYbpfwVad1oQeyG4s9Er)
2. Log in (choose your ID to use there, e.g. `klu9@zeroid.bit`)
3. Click on your ID button top right and click "My Channels".
4. Click the big plus sign to create a new channel. (You might have to choose a "Cluster" first, and "Grant Merger" with it. And no, I don't know what a "cluster" is. Maybe something like a hub on ZeroMe...?)
5. Give your channel a name and description.
6. On your channel page, click "Upload" (or drag files onto the upload area).
7. You can set some details of the file (e.g. "audio", "misc")
Files will upload.
(I notice no option at this point to describe the files.)
8. Click on an uploaded file to view its individual page.

![IFS - file page](img\IFS.file.page.png)
[Full size image](img\IFS.file.page.png)

Here are the IFS pages for the files I uploaded:
+ [Steal This Show - 2019-02-05 - Software will Eat the World, with @Rabble - Part 1](http://127.0.0.1:43110/12MVkvYGcRW6u2NYbpfwVad1oQeyG4s9Er/index.html?view:item+id:1Mz1_131Seivv6aH8vnohPmYPcPwPfZ1a5ubMMs_item_1+type:audio)
+ [Steal This Show - 2019-03-01 - Software will Eat the World, with @Rabble - Part 2](http://127.0.0.1:43110/12MVkvYGcRW6u2NYbpfwVad1oQeyG4s9Er/index.html?view:item+id:1Mz1_131Seivv6aH8vnohPmYPcPwPfZ1a5ubMMs_item_2+type:audio)

On a file's individual page on IFS, you can
+ play the file on the page, in the embedded player at top
+ see info about the file: name, number of peers, size, etc
+ vote the file up or down
+ delete the file (if you are the uploader, presumably)
+ download the file
+ see an "Embed Code" that can be copied (I will try using this in a moment)
+ comment on the file

Also, just under the embedded player, it says "Download finished!" I guess this is because I have the whole file already on my computer.

As there is no option to provide a description of the file, I made a comment about it. I kept it short, because nowadays I'm wary of running out of space for things like comments on zites. (The IFS comment window doesn't indicate space used, so I opened the zite's side panel to see how much space is allowed to me for things like comments, but the "IDENTITY ADDRESS" section there said "0KB/0KB"... so I don't know what the limit is. Maybe unlimited?)

## Part 2: Embedding the audio here on my blog
IFS handily provides an "Embed Code" on a file's page, with a blue "Copy" button.

I clicked the "Copy" button and pasted the code in my blog post.

Here's what the code looks like:
`merged-CDN/1MzV32sv55VSD5Vr7u3mcMPsX2oG9PHusr/data/users/131Seivv6aH8vnohPmYPcPwPfZ1a5ubMMs/Steal-This-Show--2019-02-05--software-eats-the-world-part-1-with-rabble.mp3`

And now for the embed (fingers crossed!) **Damn!** Pasting that code does **not** embed the audio on my blog, it just puts it as plain text on the page. (I thought it looked a little "bare"; it's just an URL rather than code.) I guess it needs some HTML around it. I first thought of tweaking the HTML code I used for video in [my post about embedding video](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1Ctjcvfovq6d1JWEGvM1JovCym4H6Es33L/?Post:8:Experimenting+with+uploads:+video), but I DuckDuckGoed (DuckDuckWent?) "html embed audio code" and found this page [W3schools - HTML5 Audio](https://www.w3schools.com/html/html5_audio.asp) which gives the following example code:
`<audio controls>`
  `<source src="horse.ogg" type="audio/ogg">`
  `<source src="horse.mp3" type="audio/mpeg">`
`Your browser does not support the audio element.`
`</audio>`

As the files are .mp3's, I'll get rid of the line about .ogg format, and change the "horse.mp3" part to the embed code from IFS for my file, which looks like this:
`<audio controls>`
    `<source src="merged-CDN/1MzV32sv55VSD5Vr7u3mcMPsX2oG9PHusr/data/users/131Seivv6aH8vnohPmYPcPwPfZ1a5ubMMs/Steal-This-Show--2019-02-05--software-eats-the-world-part-1-with-rabble.mp3" type="audio/mpeg">`
`Your browser does not support the audio element.`
`</audio>`

Edit: That didn't work either. The audio players were displayed, but the Play button was greyed out. SSDifnskdjfnsdjk analyzed what was going on in the web page (pressing `F12` in the browser) and saw that the final URL produced was too long. It seems changing `merged-CDN` to `http://127.0.0.1:43110` might work.

So the code now is:
`<audio controls>`
`    <source src="http://127.0.0.1:43110/1MzV32sv55VSD5Vr7u3mcMPsX2oG9PHusr/data/users/131Seivv6aH8vnohPmYPcPwPfZ1a5ubMMs/Steal-This-Show--2019-02-05--software-eats-the-world-part-1-with-rabble.mp3" type="audio/mpeg">`
`Your browser does not support the audio element.`
`</audio>`

And now for the embed, attempt #3!

**Steal This Show - 2019-02-05 - Software will Eat the World, with @Rabble - Part 1**
<audio controls>
    <source src="http://127.0.0.1:43110/1MzV32sv55VSD5Vr7u3mcMPsX2oG9PHusr/data/users/131Seivv6aH8vnohPmYPcPwPfZ1a5ubMMs/Steal-This-Show--2019-02-05--software-eats-the-world-part-1-with-rabble.mp3" type="audio/mpeg">
Your browser does not support the audio element.
</audio>

**Steal This Show - 2019-03-01 - Software will Eat the World, with @Rabble - Part 2**
<audio controls>
    <source src="http://127.0.0.1:43110/1MzV32sv55VSD5Vr7u3mcMPsX2oG9PHusr/data/users/131Seivv6aH8vnohPmYPcPwPfZ1a5ubMMs/Steal-This-Show--2019-03-01--software-eats-the-world-part-2-with-rabble.mp3" type="audio/mpeg">
Your browser does not support the audio element.
</audio>

Hopefully you can see the embedded audio players and use them to play the mp3's! It's possible you might have to "Grant merger" with IFS for the audio to load. Please let me know what happens for you in the comments.

(I wish IFS would give the **full** code with **full working** URL to embed the file. It would have saved a lot of trouble.)

post.title: Quick test with Apertium offline translator
post.body:
On ZeroTalk, I've been participating in the topic [Is there a program for Linux that will translate language that will run on your computer without going to the cloud to do it?](http://127.0.0.1:43110/Talk.ZeroNetwork.bit/?Topic:1548909076_1AdWXZdPUimpXoGNXUBde2CHR7gLf4onxE) Basically it's about offline machine translation, as online tools like Google Translate are a serious privacy concern. (See that thread and [this video](http://127.0.0.1:43110/Me.ZeroNetwork.bit/?Post/12h51ug6CcntU2aiBjhP8Ns2e5VypbWWtv/131Seivv6aH8vnohPmYPcPwPfZ1a5ubMMs/1549142235) for more.) And about trying to find an option that is preferably open source and that can run on Linux.

I decided to give one option a quick try: [Apertium Simpleton UI](http://wiki.apertium.org/wiki/Apertium_Simpleton_UI) (henceforth "ASUI"), a simple GUI version of the [Apertium](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Apertium) machine translation engine, available for several OSes.

---
## Installing
