+ I downloaded and extracted the version for my OS. (I'm on Windows for now so I went with the Windows file.)
+ I ran it, and the built-in package installer opens.
+ I clicked "Install" for "Required Core Tools".

It started downloading, and completed I think.
But the Package Installer list still showed a clickable "Install" button next to "Required Core Tools". So, thinking maybe all it had done was download and I still needed to do something to actually make it install, I clicked the button again.

But it started downloading all over again. I clicked "Cancel", which worked... for a second and then the download started again. I tried "Cancel" a few more times, and always the download would restart after a second. So I just let it download again.

And still the Package list is the same as before, with the clickable "Install" button. Oh well, let's just proceed anyway. (But really there should be some change once the file has installed, like removing the item or making the button unclickable, or just changing "Install" to "Installed".) (EDIT: I noticed that the next time I opened the Package Installer, the buttons for items that I had already installed were now relabelled "Reinstall".)

![Apertium Simpleton package installer](img/Apertium-Simpleton-package-installer.png)
[Apertium Simpleton package installer - full size image](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1Ctjcvfovq6d1JWEGvM1JovCym4H6Es33L/img/Apertium-Simpleton-package-installer.png)

---
## Languages
The next step was to choose and install language packs, which are made for specific language pairings. The package list only gives two- or three-letter codes for the languages, so I made sure I had this webpage open: [Apertium Wiki - List of language pairs](http://wiki.apertium.org/wiki/List_of_language_pairs), which explains the codes.

I already knew from a little reading & online practice that Apertium is funded by Spanish government bodies, and that Spanish or Catalan is often used as a bridge language (i.e. an intermediate language to go through, a workaround when the software doesn't have packages to translate directly between two specific languages).

So for those reasons, and because I'm familiar with this language pairing for verification purposes (i.e. I can check if the translation is any good), I downloaded the `apertium en-es` package for English and Spanish.

(By the way, the app, the core files and the language pack were all a lot smaller than I expected. The Apertium folder was just under 25MB. The language pack downloads were just a couple of megabytes each. They are unpacked and stored elsewhere. In Windows, it was in `C:\Users\klu9\AppData\Roaming\Tino Didriksen Consult\Apertium Simpleton` and subfolders, which took up 114MB.)

I closed the package installer and looked at the main program. There was now an "eng-spa" displayed at the top left, with a "Run" button next to it.

---
## Translating
In ASUI's top window, I typed
> Hello World

and clicked "Run".
After a second or two, the bottom box displayed
> *Hola Mundo*

Success! At least, success with an extremely tiny basic sample.

![Apertium Simpleton - Hello World](img\Apertium.en.es.hola.mundo.png)

So next sample:
> Let's try a longer sentence.

After a couple of seconds, the bottom box showed:
> *Dejado es probar una frase más larga.*

Oh dear. The last part is alright: "*una frase más larga*" does mean "a longer sentence".

But the first half is gibberish.
1. {`"Let's" + basic verb form`} is the way that the English language creates a first-person-plural imperative.
But "*Dejado*" is the past participle of the verb "*dejar*", with, yes, the sense of "let", "allow" but also "leave", "abandon", "give up". And it is *never* used in Spanish to make a a first-person-plural imperative the way "Let's" is used in English.
So what Apertium has given here is something sort of with the meaning "Given up" or "[is] allowed/ [is]left / [is] abandoned".
2. {`´s`}is a contraction in English. Here it's a contraction of "Let ***us***" (remember, we're making a first-person plural imperative, hence "us".) But Apertium has apparently interpreted it as a contraction for "is" (third person singular form of the verb "be") and has given us "*es*" (third person singular form of the verb "*ser*")
3. `probar` is the infinitive form of a verb that can have the meaning "to try". So the meaning is OK, but the grammar is wrong.

So all together, "*Dejado es probar una frase más larga*" sort of gives us "Given up is to try a longer sentence."

A better translation would be like:
> *Probemos una frase más larga.*

I'm very disappointed. "Let's (verb)" is very basic stuff, the kind of thing that people learn in their first few months of English as Second Language classes. Moreover, I'm going from English, a well-known, major language that's official for both the EU and the UN, to Spanish, which is not only another well-known language major language that's official for both the EU and the UN but also one relevant to the Apertium makers themselves. And yet Apertium has thrown a complete wobbly over something so simple. It's given me the kind of thing that gets posted on social media for a laugh. Why has no one at Apertium caught this before now? This does not bode well.

To confirm whether or not this is limited to just ASUI, I try the online instance of Apertium at https://apertiumtrad.tuxfamily.org/tradtexte.php , and (once I ticked "Direct translation") it produced the exact same result. :(

I try a few more sentences, ones from this article.
> I'm very disappointed.

> *Soy muy decepcionado.*

Spanish has two verbs, *ser* and *estar*, that can both be translations of the English verb "be". *Soy* is the first person-singular of *ser*. But to describe an emotional state, the verb *estar* should be used. So it should really be *Estoy muy decepcionado*.

> This does not bode well.

> `Esto  no *bode bien.`

Apparently, prefixing with an asterisk `*` is Apertium's way of saying it doesn't know the word and has just left it in the original language.

At this point I notice: there's no "Back" or history function in Apertium Simpleton UI, so when I want to find previous translations, I can't and have to run them all over again. A small point, but an issue nonetheless.

> I try a few more sentences, ones from this article.

> *Pruebo unos cuantos más frases, unos de esta prenda.*

That's not ***too*** bad... until the last word. "Article" is a word that can have several meanings, and that's the kind of thing that can throw even human translators, and can only be determined by context. It's an area where advanced machine translation like Google Translate has been getting *much* better over the years. In this case, I meant "article" in the sense of a piece of published writing (which would be *artículo* in Spanish), but Apertium has translated it in the sense of an article/item of clothing, hence "*prenda*".

One small issue is that, in the English original "ones" refers back to "sentences". So in the Spanish translation, it should be "*unas*" (feminine plural) both times, to match "*frases*" (feminine plural).

Also it's more natural in Spanish to put "*más*" after "*frases*". But you would still be understood (at least up until it throws out "*prenda*".)

So this tells me that when the meaning is ambiguous, 
1. It does not offer options (like a CAT would). It just picks one.
2. It can pick the wrong one. And if the user doesn't know the languages involved, they would not even know it.
3. Less importantly, it's not good at matching grammar of words in different places of the sentence (e.g. feminine plural article to match feminine plural noun).

By now, I've noticed that Apertium Simpleton GUI has no option for translating through a bridge language.

On https://apertiumtrad.tuxfamily.org/tradtexte.php for example, there is no direct translation between English and French, but it can use Spanish as a bridge language to go from English to Spanish and finally to French.

But good news! Apertium Simpleton UI doesn't just access the "Validated" class of language pairings (listed under "Trunk" on [Apertium Wiki - List of language pairs](http://wiki.apertium.org/wiki/List_of_language_pairs)) that the website uses, but also the other less mature classes of language pairs, listed under "Staging", "Nursery" and "Incubator". And so the Apertium Simpleton package installer offers `apertium en-fr` as an option. Let's try that!

After using the package installer to download the English-French package, the ASUI top left button now shows `en-fr` by default, and the dropdown menu now shows a range of option for both French & English, and the previously installed Spanish & English pairings.

> I try a few more sentences, ones from this article.

After a few seconds:
> *Je tente @a few @more phrases, #un de #ce article.*

![Apertium Simpleton - English to French](img\Apertium.en.fr.menu.png)

Oh boy. I guess the `@` prefix means it hasn't even tried to translate the word (although why en-fr uses `@` but eng-spa uses `*`, I don't know). And we're not talking difficult, obscure words, just " a few more".

The `#`... I don't know. Maybe at a guess it means that the word gender & number is variable depending upon context. (Masculine *un* (singular) / *uns* plural, feminine *une* (sing.) / *unes* plural). I can understand why it does that. But it should know the right form of "*ce*" to match the French word *article* rather than consider it an uncertainty.

There is no built-in explanation of symbols or help file in Apertium Simpleton UI. The "File" menu contains only one option: "Exit".

## Comparison with online translators
Before concluding, let's check what's produced by online translators.

Key:
+ ASUI= Apertium Simpleton UI.
+ ATF = [Apertium online at Tuxfamily.org](https://apertiumtrad.tuxfamily.org/tradtexte.php).
+ GT = Google Translate.
+ PNMT = [Pure Neural Machine Translation demo from Systran](https://demo-pnmt.systran.net/production#/translation).
+ (+) = good
+ (X) = bad
+ (/) = so-so

### English to Spanish
+ **English: Hello World**
+ ASUI: Hola Mundo (+) 
+ ATF: Hola Mundo (+) 
+ GT: Hola Mundo (+) 
+ PNMT: Hola World (X)

---
+ **English: Let's try a longer sentence.**
+ ASUI: Dejado es probar una frase más larga. (X)
+ ATF: Dejado es probar una frase más larga. (X)
+ GT: Probemos una oración más larga. (+) 
+ PNMT: Intentemos una sentencia más larga. (+) 

Re GT: "*oración*" is a valid alternative to "*frase*".
Re PNMT: The verb *intentar* is another way to say "to try", so "*Intentemos*" is a valid alternative here.

---
+ **English: I'm very disappointed.**
+ ASUI: Soy muy decepcionado. (/)
+ ATF: Soy muy decepcionado. (/)
+ GT: Estoy muy decepcionado. (+)
+ PNMT: Estoy muy decepcionado por eso. ("I'm very disappointed by that." Why PNMT has added "by that", I've no idea.) (/)

---
+ **English: This does not bode well.**
+ ASUI: Esto no *bode bien. (X)
+ ATF: Esto no *bode bien. (X)
+ GT: Esto no augura nada bueno. (+)
+ PNMT: Esto no es un buen augurio. (+)

Both GT and PNMT have gone for options that do not exactly parallel word-for-word the structure of what I wrote (subject + negative verb + adverb) but are good ways of expressing what I meant.

---
+ **English: I try a few more sentences, ones from this article.**
+ ASUI: Pruebo unos cuantos más frases, unos de esta prenda. (X)
+ ATF: Pruebo unos cuantos más frases, unos de esta prenda. (X)
+ GT: Intento unas cuantas oraciones más, las de este artículo. (/)
+ PNMT: Intento algunas frases más, algunas de este artículo. (+)

Re GT: "*las*" for "ones" in the final clause to me implies *all* the sentences in the article, not just some. It's more like "the ones", not just "ones".
Re PNMT: it's gone for "*algunas*" in both clauses, a valid option.
Both GT & PNMT went for "*Intento*", a valid alternative to "*Pruebo*".

### English to French

+ **English: I try a few more sentences, ones from this article.**
+ ASUI: Je tente @a few @more phrases, #un de #ce article. (X)
+ ATF: J'essaie quelques *cuantos plus phrases, uns de cette pièce. (X)
+ GT: J'essaie quelques phrases supplémentaires, celles de cet article. (+)
+ PNMT: J'essaie quelques phrases, celles de cet article. (/)

Re ATF: ATF allows using a bridge language, and I selected Spanish to get from English to French, which is how we ended up with "**cuantos*" in there. The rest of it seems fine though, with "*cette pièce*" as a valid way of translating "this article" is the sense of a piece of writing. Although the final clause's "*uns*" (masculine plural) should probably be "*unes*" (feminine plural) to match the gender of "*phrases*".
Re PNMT: I see nothing to give the idea of "more".
My dictionary says both verbs "*essayer*" and "*tenter*" can be used for "to try".



## Conclusion
Well, this has been just a very quick test of Apertium Simpleton UI as an alterntive to Google Translate. Here's a summary.

**The good points**
+ Offline and private
+ Free-libre / open source
+ Free-gratis (both the app and the language packs)
+ Multi-platform (Windows, Linux, Mac)
+ Built-in package manager for language packs
+ Quick and easy to install the app and the language packs
+ Easy to use
+ Relatively small (App 25MB. Two language packs: only about 4MB to download, about 114MB when unpacked)
+ Light (using only 15MB of RAM)

**The major bad points**
+ Very limited choice of validated language pairings (e.g. not even English-French).
+ The quality of translation for the validated language pairings (e.g. English-Spanish) ranges from "just about acceptable" to "absolutely awful".
+ The quality of translation for the unvalidated language pairings (e.g. English-French) is even worse, with many words not even translated.
+ Doesn't even allow the option to use a bridge language (e.g. English to Spanish to French), to try to get better results for unvalidated language pairings.

**The minor bad points**
+ Many of the language packs are updated infrequently
+ No built-in help or info
+ Only uses two- or three- letter codes to indicate languages
+ No history or back function
+ No automatic detection of input language
+ No immediate update in package installer to show a package has been successfully installed
+ Can take a few seconds after pressing "Run" to translate sentences (whereas Google Translate is instantaneous, not even a click required).

Overall, ASUI is ***not*** yet a replacement for a good quality online machine translation service like Google Translate. The *minor* bad points I can overlook, but the *major* bad points are showstoppers, for me at least.

So I guess we need to keep looking. If you know of, or find, another option for offline, free-libre, multi-platform translation, please let us know in the comments or the [ZeroTalk thread](http://127.0.0.1:43110/Talk.ZeroNetwork.bit/?Topic:1548909076_1AdWXZdPUimpXoGNXUBde2CHR7gLf4onxE).

post.title: Experimenting with uploads: video
post.body:
So now I'm going to upload video to Zeronet and hopefully embed it in my blog.

<video src="http://127.0.0.1:43110/18Pfr2oswXvD352BbJvo59gZ3GbdbipSzh/data/users/131Seivv6aH8vnohPmYPcPwPfZ1a5ubMMs/1551122501-How.to.Disappear.Completely--Lilly.Ryan--Linux.Conf.Au.2019.mp4" controls="" width="600" height="400"></video>

Source (click this link if you can't see the video here): [How.to.Disappear.Completely--Lilly.Ryan--Linux.Conf.Au.2019.mp4](http://127.0.0.1:43110/18Pfr2oswXvD352BbJvo59gZ3GbdbipSzh/?Video=1551122501_131Seivv6aH8vnohPmYPcPwPfZ1a5ubMMs)

## Part 1 - Getting a video
I saw a video on YouTube I wanted, but also knew YouTube likes to block downloading of videos.
At first I tried a download manager I already have installed, [uGet](https://ugetdm.com/). But:
+ the download speed was capped at 30kbps
+ it was getting the video in 360p, even though higher resolutions were available.

I remembered a tool I'd heard of over the years, called [youtube-dl](https://github.com/rg3/youtube-dl). It's a command line tool, and I prefer GUI programs, but I thought I'd give it a try anyway.

1. I got youtube-dl.exe (for Windows) from https://github.com/rg3/youtube-dl
2. I watched [this short video tutorial](http://127.0.0.1:43110/big.kopykate.bit/?Video=1551131515_131Seivv6aH8vnohPmYPcPwPfZ1a5ubMMs) for a quick idea of how to use it.
3. I downloaded the video by writing the following in the CMD window:
`youtube-dl.exe "https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LOulCAz4S0M"`
That got me the video in 720p.
(In Linux, you don't even need the `.exe`or the quotes around the URL, apparently.)

---
+ There's also a GUI tool based on youtube-dl, called [youtube-dl GUI](https://github.com/MrS0m30n3/youtube-dl-gui), which I also used for subsequent downloads. See this [ZeroMe post with a little more on youtube-dl and youtube-dl GUI](http://127.0.0.1:43110/Me.ZeroNetwork.bit/?Post/12h51ug6CcntU2aiBjhP8Ns2e5VypbWWtv/131Seivv6aH8vnohPmYPcPwPfZ1a5ubMMs/1551139681) including video tutorials.
+ @deliriumgoddess: mentioned a simple online tool to grab individual videos off YouTube and other sites: [Savefrom.net](https://en.savefrom.net/)

## Part 2 - Uploading the video
1. I moved the file to another folder and renamed it, so that the name was more informative and to eliminate spaces, which can complicate linking.
2. I went to 0net's equivalent of YouTube, [KopyKate](http://127.0.0.1:43110/18Pfr2oswXvD352BbJvo59gZ3GbdbipSzh), and clicked the Upload icon at top right of the page.
3. I gave the video a title and description.
4. I saw there was the option to upload a thumbnail. I took a screenshot and tried uploading. I got the following error message:
> Max image size: 25kb (Tip: use GIMP or online compression tools to reduce resolution/quality!)
5. In an image editor, I made adjustments to the original screenshot (572kb png), cropped and compressed until it became a 24.8kb jpg. (I probably should have just resized the image, as it's going to be a thumbnail.)
6. I clicked "Publish".
> Content published to 5 peers
7. I turned off BitTorrent, so that all my (rather limited) upload bandwidth was dedicated to Zeronet and seeding the video.

## Part 3 - Posting the video
The video was already on KopyKate, visible in the "Airing Now" section (which displays the latest uploads). But I wanted to post it elsewhere.

1. I made [a post about the video on ZeroMe](http://127.0.0.1:43110/Me.ZeroNetwork.bit/?Post/12h51ug6CcntU2aiBjhP8Ns2e5VypbWWtv/131Seivv6aH8vnohPmYPcPwPfZ1a5ubMMs/1551124392), giving the URL for the KopyKate page (as videos cannot be embedded in ZeroMe posts). Here's the [markdown](http://127.0.0.1:43110/138R53t3ZW7KDfSfxVpWUsMXgwUnsDNXLP/?Page:markdown) I put in my ZeroMe post:
`[How to disappear completely](http://127.0.0.1:43110/big.kopykate.bit/?Video=1551122501_131Seivv6aH8vnohPmYPcPwPfZ1a5ubMMs)`
This ZeroMe post quickly informed people about the video, drawing viewers and thus peers who can seed the video to other people, so that I (with my crappy bandwidth) wouldn't be the only source for too long. After 2 days, it's already got 10 peers.
2. To embed it here on my blog, I created a new post and, after trying something else, put this html:
`<video src="http://127.0.0.1:43110/big.kopykate.bit/data/users/131Seivv6aH8vnohPmYPcPwPfZ1a5ubMMs/1551122501-How.to.Disappear.Completely--Lilly.Ryan--Linux.Conf.Au.2019.mp4" controls="" width="600" height="400"></video>`
And here it is without the URL for my video (to ease copying and pasting). Put the URL for your video between the quotes after **video src=**.
`<video src="" controls="" width="600" height="400"></video>`

---
I originally tried the following markdown **which did not work**:
`![How to Disappear Completely - a talk about facial recognition and how to beat it](http://127.0.0.1:43110/big.kopykate.bit/data/users/131Seivv6aH8vnohPmYPcPwPfZ1a5ubMMs/1551122501-How.to.Disappear.Completely--Lilly.Ryan--Linux.Conf.Au.2019.mp4)`

In a [ZeroTalk topic about this](http://127.0.0.1:43110/Talk.ZeroNetwork.bit/?Topic:1551299295_131Seivv6aH8vnohPmYPcPwPfZ1a5ubMMs) @kai0: recommended using the HTML code, and that worked!

@gluek: & @toyata: brought up an important point. Because of the way that Zeronet works, if a visitor to my blog has never visited KopyKate before, a KopyKate-hosted video will not load for them here on my blog. So it's probably a good idea to always provide a direct link for any embedded video hosted on another zite.

Originally, I used all the code @kai0: gave, but @SSDifnskdjfnsdjk: pointed out that the video auto-played when loading my blog (I hate that, but didn't realize because I have an extension to prevent that). So I cut out `autoplay=""`.

@gluek: mentioned some techniques to host a video on my own zite (not KopyKate) involving [optional files](http://127.0.0.1:43110/138R53t3ZW7KDfSfxVpWUsMXgwUnsDNXLP/?Page:optional-files) which @ssdifnskdjfnsdjk: goes into more here: [ZeroTalk - How to create static site with big streamable videos](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1TaLkFrMwvbNsooF4ioKAY9EuxTBTjipT/?Topic:1545035786_1L4dZcDF2maSKHDy788yhxpYnBWnXadUtS)

But that's an experiment for another day. Right now, I'm just glad I can embed a KopyKate video in my blog post.

Thanks to everyone who gave feedback and advice, here, on ZeroTalk and [ZeroMe](http://127.0.0.1:43110/Me.ZeroNetwork.bit/?Post/12h51ug6CcntU2aiBjhP8Ns2e5VypbWWtv/131Seivv6aH8vnohPmYPcPwPfZ1a5ubMMs/1551374324).

post.title: Big comparison of secure / anonymous / decentralized / private communication systems
post.body:
The folks behind [**secushare**](https://secushare.org/introduction), a [GNU Project](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/GNU_Project) to make a secure, private communications and filesharing system, have over the years written up a big comparison of various programs, networks, protocols and more with a focus on security, privacy, anonymity, decentralization etc. It is a very long but fascinating read (that even I, as a non-developer, was able to mostly understand. Mostly.)

+ Original Link: 
[**secushare.org - Capability Comparison**](https://secushare.org/comparison)
+ My mirror here on ZeroNet: [Capability Comparison](data\SecushareComparison\Capability Comparison.htm)	

It's organized into sections around the following uses:
+ Social Networking
+ File Exchange
+ Instant Messaging
+ Asynchronous Messaging (E-Mail)
+ Telephony and Video Conferencing
+ Chatroom Idling

It covers areas like:
+ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Secure_communication
+ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anonymous_P2P
+ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anonymous_blog
+ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Private_peer-to-peer
+ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Friend-to-friend

It gives their definitions of key terms like:
+ [centralized](https://secushare.org/centralization)
+ decentralized
+ distributed
+ [federated](https://secushare.org/federation)

It assesses these systems on the above and on issues like security, privacy, and scalability, and at the end of each section offers a "BEST CURRENT PRACTICE RECOMMENDATION".

Just a few of those mentioned in the comparison that might be of interest to ZeroNet users: **cjdns, I2P & I2PBote, RetroShare, BitMessage, Matrix/Riot, Secure Scuttlebutt, Telegram, Tribler, Wire**. But no mention of ZeroNet :/

And it is very, **very** opinionated :) While some are praised, and some mentioned only in passing, most come in for criticism: lots of scathing criticism! Who knew darknets could be so bitchy! Maybe it's a good thing they don't discuss ZeroNet :)

While the comparison is very informative, it mentions **so** many things but offers only a few links with more info. I know about or have heard of a lot of them, but also a lot were new to me. So I'm putting here a big list with links for most of these systems, protocols, programs, principles, and vulnerabilities. You can use it to find out more as you read the comparison or just scan the list so as understand what they're talking about... or to see if your favourite is in the comparison and brace yourself for the drubbing they give it. (There's a lot more interesting stuff on the [secushare website](https://secushare.org/).)

Most links go to clearnet Wikipedia.

---
### Issues, principles, vulnerabilities, threats
+ [deniability](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Plausible_deniability#Use_in_computer_networks)
+ [distributed hash table (DHT)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distributed_hash_table)
+ [end-to-end encryption (E2EE)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/End-to-end_encryption)
+ group encryption
+ [Five Eyes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Five_Eyes) - cooperation among intelligence agencies to spy on each other's residents
+ [forward secrecy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Forward_secrecy)
+ link/URL encryption (other people seeing the URLS you visit is a key identity-revealing vulnerability as seen in [this DEFCON video](http://127.0.0.1:43110/peeper.bit/?Post/1AbRRDveQD5EFtmXxBqQfS1guUWXxytMJZ/131Seivv6aH8vnohPmYPcPwPfZ1a5ubMMs/1549142235))
+ [Logjam attack](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Logjam_(computer_security%29)
+ [Man-in-the-middle attack](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Man-in-the-middle_attack)
+ [metadata protection](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Metadata#Telecommunications)
+ [moderating forums](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internet_forum#Moderators)
+ [multicasting](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multicast)
+ [PRISM](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PRISM_(surveillance_program%29) - US surveillance of internet traffic
+ [PubSub](https://secushare.org/pubsub) - system for multicasting
+ relays
+ [Sybil attack](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sybil_attack)
+ Unobservability
+ [Untraceability](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Digital_footprint)

---
### Programs, networks, protocols, services, companies etc
Most in the list have some focus on privacy, security, anonymity, decentralization etc, and most are open source. (I've italicized a few that might be of special relevance to: me or ZeroNet users or this comparison from secushare.)
+ [Adobe Flash](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adobe_Flash)'s RTMP and RTMFP protocols
+ [*BitMessage*](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bitmessage) - e-mail alternative
+ [*BitTorrent*](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/BitTorrent) - filesharing protocol
+ [Briar](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Briar_(software%29) - mobile instant messaging
+ [Bubcon](https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.bubcon.messenger&hl=en_US) - mobile instant messaging
+ [Buddycloud](http://buddycloud.com/) - instant messaging
+ [ChatSecure](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ChatSecure) + [Orbot](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Orbot) - mobile instant messaging over Tor
+ [*cjdns*](https://github.com/cjdelisle/cjdns/) - alternative to DNS system, which is where a lot of censorship/blocking happens
+ [crypto.cat](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cryptocat) - instant messaging
+ [Diaspora*](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Diaspora_(social_network%29) - social network
+ [DSNP](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distributed_Social_Networking_Protocol) - social network
+ The [EFF](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electronic_Frontier_Foundation) and its [secure messaging scorecard](https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2018/03/secure-messaging-more-secure-mess)
+ Facebook
+ [*F-Droid*](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/F-Droid) - open source Android app store
+ [*Freenet*](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Freenet) - P2P network
+ [Friendica](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Friendica) - social network
+ [*GNUnet*](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/GNUnet) - P2P protocol
+ [Google Allo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Google_Allo) - mobile instant messaging
+ [Google Hangouts](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Google_Hangouts) - communications platform
+ [Human Connection](https://human-connection.org/) - social network
+ [*I2P*](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/I2P) - network
+ [I2PBote](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/I2P#Email) - e-mail alternative using I2P
+ [*IRC*](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IRC) - chat protocol
+ [Jingle](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jingle_(protocol%29) - voice protocol
+ [Jitsi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jitsi) - IM, voice, video calls
+ [Maidsafe/SAFE Network](https://safenetwork.tech/) - P2P web with cryptocurrency
+ [Manyverse](https://www.manyver.se/) - mobile social network on Secure Scuttlebutt
+ [*Matrix*](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Matrix_(protocol%29) (cross-network communications) & [*Riot.im*](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Riot.im) (chat & filesharing on Matrix)
+ [Moxie Marlinspike](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Moxie_Marlinspike) - developer of the Signal protocol used by Signal, WhatsApp etc
+ [Movim](https://movim.eu/) - social network over XMPP
+ [Mumble](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mumble_(software%29) - voice
+ [Nightweb](https://sekao.net/nightweb/) - discontinued, social blogging over I2P and BitTorrent
+ [OMEMO](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/OMEMO) - encryption extension for XMPP
+ [Onionshare](https://onionshare.org/) - filesharing
+ [OTR](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Off-the-Record_Messaging) - encryption extension for XMPP
+ [OwnCloud](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/OwnCloud) - Filesharing / hosting
+ [PGP](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pretty_Good_Privacy) - e-mail encryption
+ [Pond](https://github.com/agl/pond) - [e-mail alternative over Tor](https://medium.com/@undercomm/secure-communication-pond-4985bfe85a2c)
+ [*PSYC*](https://about.psyc.eu/) and its social network [*psyced*](https://about.psyc.eu/psyced) - chat, IRC alternative. Apparently PSYC clients can connect to PSYC, IRC and XMPP all at the same time. (I think some of the people involved in PSYC are also involved in secushare.)
+ [*RetroShare*](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/RetroShare) - P2P communications & filesharing with friends only
+ [Ricochet](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ricochet_(software%29) - instant messaging
+ [*Secure Scuttlebutt*](https://www.scuttlebutt.nz/) - decentralized network
+ [*secushare*](https://secushare.org/) - future program for filesharing & communication
+ [*Signal*](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Signal_(software%29) - mobile communications
+ [SILC](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SILC_(protocol%29) - conferencing, IRC-like protocol
+ [SilentPhone](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Silent_Circle_(software%29) - mobile voice & messaging for business subscribers
+ [Skype](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Skype) - voice, video, instant messaging
+ [Snapchat](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Snapchat) - mobile messaging
+ [SocialVPN](http://ipop-project.org/learn/#socialvpn) - network connection with friends, based on XMPP and [IPOP](http://ipop-project.org/about/)
+ [SureSpot](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Surespot) - mobile instant messaging
+ [*Telegram*](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Telegram_(service%29) - mobile instant messaging and voice
+ [Threema](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Threema) - mobile instant messaging and voice
+ [*Tor*](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tor_(anonymity_network%29) - network
+ [Tox](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tox_(protocol%29) - instant messaging protocol
+ [*Tribler*](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tribler) - BitTorrent filesharing with decentralized search
+ [*Twister*](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Twister_(software%29) - a microblogging platform... that is peer-to-peer, uses Bitcoin blockchain for ID and BitTorrent for distribution. Now what does that remind me of...? ;)
+ [WebRTC](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WebRTC) - audio & video conferencing protocol
+ [WhatsApp](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WhatsApp) - mobile instant messaging and voice
+ [*Wire*](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wire_(software%29) - mobile instant messaging and voice
+ [*XMPP*](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/XMPP) - protocol for messaging

post.title: Experimenting with uploads: images
post.body:
Let me try including an image in a post.

![Screenshot of Common ZeroBlog](img\common zeroblog screenshot 2019-1-2.png)
[Full size 970x448, 13.4KB](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1Ctjcvfovq6d1JWEGvM1JovCym4H6Es33L/img/common%20zeroblog%20screenshot%202019-1-2.png)

I did this by placing the image in the `img` folder my blog's folder, which in my case is located at:
* `C:\Users\Klu9\ZeroNet-win-dist\data\1Ctjcvfovq6d1JWEGvM1JovCym4H6Es33L\img`

And then putting in this blog post the markdown image tag:
* `![Screenshot of Common ZeroBlog](img\common zeroblog screenshot 2019-1-2.png)`

That shows the image, but at reduced size. I can't click on it to see it at full size. I wonder if there's a way to do that.

EDIT: Added link to full size, per SSD's suggestion.

post.title: A summary of ZeroNet for newbs (like me)
post.body:
So someone on ZeroTalk made a post:
> [Im brand new and i dont really get this. How does this all work???](http://127.0.0.1:43110/Talk.ZeroNetwork.bit/?Topic:1546138183_12NqXRG5Ur6HzBsgR2kgPxmcWGhR9sxSLi)

I gave a reply which I *think* sums it up:
> It's like you've just expanded your internet to include another piece: now with ZeroNet installed, you can also surf ZeroNet sites and download ZeroNet files. You can also make your own ZeroNet site (quickly & easily) without having to worry about finding (and paying) a host, because just by having ZeroNet turned on, we are all helping each other out with hosting and getting sites and files: we don't depend on companies doing it for us (for a price: either our money or our privacy).

> As a bonus, you can (with a few simple steps) do all this in a way that can't be blocked or tracked by third parties like governments, big data marketing companies etc.

> That at least is my summary, but I'm also new here. Welcome!

Is that about right? Any (newb-suitable) changes you'd make?

EDIT:
Suggestion from Styromaniac:
> we are all helping each other out with hosting and getting sites and files

to
>visitors help out with distributing important files from sites they visit and optional files they elect to download

post.title: My first post on my ZeroNet blog
post.body:
(Or should I say "zlog"? Or "bl0g" with a zero?)

So far ZeroNet (on Windows) has been a lot easier than I imagined a web alternative (darknet, decentralized web, whatever) would be.

I've installed it, done the basics, learned a few things, and run into some problems too, but no showstoppers. I know I have a lot more to learn but so far it feels within my ability range if I put some time into it. And other users are proving to be a great help.

So thanks ZeroNet and here's to a bright 2019.
